THIS is the peak time of travel, and a good time for a vicarious trip in the world of stamps, a trip that is edifying and scenic, yet without the hassle of rising costs for fares, food and lodgings.

2 woman hostages are released on Sept 16 by Japanese terrorists who have been in control of French Embassy in The Hague, Netherlands, since Sept 13; Dutch police official says release showed that significant progress has been made in negotiations with terrorists to turn over remaining 9 hostages; 2 women, 1 identified as telephone operator and other as sec, are said to be in weak condition; terrorists, who have identified themselves as members of Japanese Red Army, are still holding French Amb Jacques Senard and 8 other hostages; other signs that officials are making progress in negotiations include sending of French Boeing 707 airplane from Paris to Schiphol Airport in response to 1 of terrorists' demands; Netherlands govt source indicates that negotiations involved plans for possible trip in police vehicle from The Hague to Schiphol Airport; it is understood that 3 terrorists had told negotiators that they would release some hostages before undertaking trip or would exchange them for another unidentified hostage provided by French; diplomatic sources rept that terrorists had demanded ransom of $1-million for release of hostages along with safe passage to an unknown destination that they had originally requested; ransom demand reptdly was made through diplomatic channels to Japanese Govt and not to Dutch or French officials; efforts to raise money are understood to be underway; Netherlands Premier Joop M den Uyl issues Statement suggesting that further negotiations on possible exchange of hostages for Japanese prisoner in France be carried out between terrorists and French Govt; says French Govt has said that it is prepared to release prisoner, identified as Yutaka Furuya (M)

Two women hostages were released early today, by the Japanese terrorists who had been in control of the French Embassy since Friday afternoon. A Dutch police official said the release showed that significant progress had been made in the negotiations of the terrorists to turn over the remaining ?? hostages seized in the ??aid on the embassy. .

As national liberation movements and international organizations put pressure on old imperial powers to yield the last shreds of once mighty overseas domains, the world's remaining colonies are fast disappearing.

Moroccan King Hassan II, seeking to head off Spanish plan to hold referendum in Spanish Sahara to decide on country's future, proposes that Spain and Morocco take dispute to Internatl Ct of Justice in The Hague, news conf; says he hopes to save lives as well as Spanish-Moroccan friendship by seeking solution through direct negotiations (S)

South African Foreign Min Hilgard Muller lr to UN Sec Gen Kurt Waldheim says that South Africans will start talks on 'future pattern of const development' in South-West Africa (Namibia); territory, once Ger colony, has been under South African adm since World War I, originally under League of Nations mandate; Internatl Ct or Justice in The Hague ruled in '73 that South Africa was illegally occupying area; UN interprets act as move to halt African-led drive to have South African delegation expelled from UN Gen Assembly; previous drives to have delegation expelled ended inconclusively; black African delegates express hope that assembly pres Min Abdelaziz Bouteflika will not follow precedent and rule that delegation should be permitted to attend (M)

UN Assembly, 98-23, with 14 abstentions, rejects Sept 30 credentials of S African delegation and calls on Security Council to rev relationship between UN and S Africa; expulsion or suspension are not presently involved, Council having to recommend either; US and GB are among nations voting no; vote for Council rev is 125-1, with 9 abstentions, including US and GB; those who abstain or vote no, including US Amb John A Scali, stress they too are opposed to racial segregation, prime objection against S Africa; move against S Africa has been led by group of African nations; Uganda Min Elizabeth Bagaya, Sept chmn of group, urges ostracizing present S African regime; S African repr Roelf F Botha defends regime and its credentials; UN Charter articles on expulsion and suspension quoted (M)

over 100,000 people fill streets around UN Nov 4, in one of largest demonstrations in NYC history, to protest Assembly inv to PLO to participate in debate on Palestine; among notables attending are Israeli ex-Foreign Min Abba Eban, Sen Henry M Jackson, Mayor Beame, Sen Javits and Ramsey Clark; PLO supporters hold counter news conf few blocks away; heavily guarded by police; illus (L)

More than 100,000 people filled the streets around the United Nations yesterday in one of the largest demonstrations in the city's history-to protest the invitation to the Palestine Liberation Organization to take part in the General Assembly debate on the Middle East.

THE HAGUE, Dec. 27 (Reuters)-South Moluccans demanding independence from Indonesia today hurled fire bombs at the. Hague Peace Palace, headquarters of the International Court of Justice, after scaling its closed gates, and smashing windows and doors.

Lionel J Leitner lr contends that auto workers should agree to 10% reduction in wages and auto cos should agree to reduce prices by 10% in effort to end severe depression in auto indus and curtail inflationary pressures in US econ

Texaco Inc becomes 4th US co to withdraw from oil venture off coast of Namibia (South-West Africa) under pressure from Church Project on US Investments in Southern Africa; UN Security Council has told South African Govt to withdraw from Namibia, which it has administered since '20, and cos hold that sovereignty issue, rather than pressure from church group, was prime motive for pull-out; Standard Oil of Calif sec H L Severance says co, only US co left in project, must either withdraw itself or find another partner; leases were granted by Namibian Govt co Swakor; other cos to have left project are Continental Oil Co, Getty Oil Co and Phillip Petroleum Co; church project chmn Donald Wilson comments; map (M)

"YOU'RE going on to The Hague? What a strange idea!" the man from Amsterdam said. "The biggest village of Holland," sophisated Amsterdamers call it, adding: "Rotterdam is where you work, Amsterdam is where you have fun, The Hague is ... where you reside."
ATHENS, Feb. 15--While the Cyprus issue has been attract ing international attention, Greece and Turkey have been waging another battle over their respective rights in the Aegean Sea.

Oman and Iran are drawing up plans to patrol waters at entrance to Persian Gulf against pollution by oil tankers; Oman's Foreign Min Qais al-Zawawi says spillage and flushing on tanks is mounting problem in recent yrs, particularly on southern side of Gulf of Oman, which the Strait of Hormuz links with Persian Gulf; says pollution will result in reprimands to shipping cos concerned or complaints to Internatl Ct of Justice at The Hague; Iran has authorized its navy to search ships within 50 miles of its coast that are thought to have been causing pollution; 2 nations have substantial experience in mil cooperation; likely internatl rules for them to apply against marine pollution would be those put forward by Intergovernmental Maritime Consultative Orgn (S)

South African Prime Min John Vorster repts that he and Foreign Min Dr Hilgard Muller and several other South African Cabinet members met with Liberian Pres William R Tolbert Jr to discuss future of South-West Africa (Namibia); says South African Govt will be glad to yield its control over territory but that withdrawal at this time would be disastrous for people of area (S)

Standard Oil of Calif withdraws from oil exploration off coast of Namibia, also known as South-West Africa, relinquishing its 45% share of lease it held jointly with Texaco Inc; Texaco, Continental Oil Co, Getty Oil Co and Phillips Petroleum have already withdrawn from Namibia; Standard sec H L Severance does not cite pressure from Church Project on US Investments in Southern Africa as factor in decision; project exec dir Timothy Smith 'exhilirated' that last US co in Namibia is leaving (S)

Article discusses unusual pol harmony in Morocco as nation prepares to mark 14th anniv of King Hassan II's accession to throne; sees harmony resulting from aggressively nationalist campaign to wrest Spanish Sahara in south, northern coastal enclaves of Ceuta and Melilla and other Spanish-held areas from Spain; drive is being waged through Internatl Court of Justice and UN Comm on Decolonization, and has won Hassan support from opposition pol forces; nation's econ problems and improved relations with Arab world revd; map (M)

US Sec Kissinger announces he will interrupt Egyptian-Israeli diplomacy on Mar 10 and fly from Israel to Ankara for unexpected talks with Turkish leaders on Cyprus situation, development follows refusal by Turkey to receive him in apparent pique over suspension by Cong of US aid because of Turkish intervention on Cyprus; Kissinger reptdly will try to persuade Turks to go along with US efforts to reconvene talks between Greek and Turkish Cypriote leaders on solving crisis and to move talks from Nicosia to UN; Kissinger met with Greek Min Dimitrios Bitsios in Brussels on Mar 7 and sent message to Ankara suggesting Mar 16 meeting in Brussels with Turkish Min Melih Esenbel; plans to conf with Turkish Pres Fahri Koruturk, Premier Sadi Irmak, Min Ilhami Sancar, former Premier Bulent Ecevit and Suleyman Demirel, in addition to Esenbel; US Asst Sec Arthur A Hartman will fly to Ankara on Mar 9 (VI)

Greek Foreign Min Dimitri Bitsios and Turkish Foreign Min Ihsan Sabri Caglayangil on May 18 hold 2d day of talks, Rome, Italy, on Cyprus dispute; express cautious optimism that tension between 2 nations might be eased; group of experts is estab to concentrate on future const set-up of Cyprus (S)
Panamanian Consul Gen Juan Antonio Stagg lr says there is need for Amers of goodwill and clear vision to become aware of Panama Canal problem and educate Amer public opinion on issues involved

3-member ILO fact-finding comm, headed by Jose Luis Bustamente y Rivero, former Peruvian Pres, with Harold S Kirkaldy and Jacques Ducoux, accuses Chilean mil Govt of having tortured labor leaders to death or executed them because of their trade union activities; comm was apptd by specialized agency of UN to investigate, with Chilean Govt agreement, complaints filed by Internatl Confed of Free Trade Unions, World Fed of Trade and many other labor groups; comm, which spent 3 wks in Chile in '74 and conferred with Govt officials, made charge in 122-page rept; notes Govt denials of executions; cites 'established fact' that many trade union leaders or former officials died after mil revolt that overthrew Pres Allende; comm reptdly submitted to Chilean Govt 'nonexhaustive list' of 110 labor leaders alleged to have been killed or executed up to end of '73; Govt confirms death of 33; repts evidence is clear that 1 of Govt's aims was to 'eliminate or prevent any large-scale opposition to its policy'; notes former trade union officials interviewed who have been held since Sept or Oct '73, have been held without formal charges; says utmost cases concern disappearance without trace of persons arrested by authorities and who cannot be identified (M)

Greek Premier Constantine Caramanlis and Turkish Premier Suleyman Demirel meet on May 31, Brussels; communique on meeting focuses on issues involving 2 Govts directly and does not mention Cyprus, source of deepest dispute; only reference to Cyprus in communique is statement that '2 Premiers agree to support intercommunal negotiations in Vienna'; support for such talks is seen as Turkish concession; move interpreted as hope by Turkish leaders that willingness to negotiate will satisfy demands in US Cong that progress be made toward settlement of Cyprus issue before embargo on US mil aid to Turkey can be lifted; illus of Caramanlis and Demirel (M)

Chilean Govt criticizes ILO rept on violations of trade union rights in Chile; Labor Under Sec Luiz Ribalta Puig says Govt will 'accept rept' since Govt had agreed to investigation by special comm; comm reptd as 'established fact' that many Chilean trade union officials had been summarily executed or had died as result of torture or in 'other circumstances' following mil revolt that overthrew Pres Allende; ILO exec council expresses 'grave concern' over comm's findings and calls on Chile to submit progress rept by Oct 1 on action it has taken on comm's recommendations for guaranteeing free exercise of trade union rights (M)

It is too early to speak of a "breakthrough" in restoring normal relations between Greece and Turkey; but a good start has been made with the agreement by Premiers Caramanlis and Demirel that their problems "must be solved peacefully." President Ford and others attending the NATO summit deserve credit for bringing about in Brussels this overdue encounter the first private talk between Greek and Turkish premiers since 1967.

Article on Brittany, France, discusses Bretons' quest for nationalist goals and rediscovery of their history; soc, econ and pol situation detailed; some residents comment; illus of pop singer Alan Stivell, who is 'hero' of Breton movement (L)

Spain is exerting pressure for 4-power agreement that would allow Spain to withdraw peacefully from Spanish Sahara; is prepared to grant independence to region but faces Moroccan and Mauritanian opposition and claims to territory; Algeria also shows concern over area's future; Spanish Foreign Min Pedro Cortina Mauri appeals for Egyptian and Arab league help in obtaining settlement that would prevent conflict following Spanish withdrawal, speech at dinner for Egyptian Foreign Min Ismail Fahmy, Madrid; Spain is proposing conf with Morocco, Mauritania and Algeria but Morocco objects to Algeria's presence on grounds that country has no real claim to Spanish Sahara; Spanish Govt had advised UN Sec Gen Kurt Waldheim, who recently toured area, that it does not want war in Spanish Sahara but will withdraw with or without agreement; UN action not expected until special mission completes rept and Intl Ct of Justice (Hague) gives judgement, probably in Aug, on Moroccan claims; role of Polisario Front, Algerian-based liberation movement, noted (M)
Prof Warren F Kimball lr scores US for agreeing to covenant that will grant Northern Marianas Islands commonwealth status (M)

LONDON The International Court of Justice at The Hague is expected to rule soon on a case brought by Morocco and Mauritania to end Madrid's control of the Wyoming-sized territory of Spanish Sahara. But whatever the court decides, the scimitarrattling over the region in the last two years has threatened to progress to a shooting war whose consequences could affect the balance of power among the Arabs and in the Western Mediterranean.

negotiations between US and Bahamas over lobstering rights have broken down, and officials are concerned about violence by Fla fishermen whose livelihoods are affected; negotiations broke down after Bahamian Govt, without presenting settlement proposal of its own, rejected $6-million Amer offer to settle issue; Amer Amb to Bahamas Seymour Weiss comments; dispute stems from recent Bahamian law that prohibits lobster fishing in area well over 100,000 sq miles of Continental Shelf; about 2,000 fishermen have been fishing area for yrs and feel restriction could mean financial ruin; small bomb exploded on Aug 27 in stern of small Bahamian freighter, which later sank to bottom of Miami River (S)
John Bickford lr sees recent Apollo-Soyuz flight representing shift in policy of confrontation between US and USSR that typified relations during '50's and '60's

US Govt has taken keen interest in internatl arbitration proceeding involving Kaiser Aluminum & Chem Corp, Alcoa and Reynolds Metals Co and Jamaican Govt over taxes on bauxite; arbitration tribunal, 3 lawyers from Denmark, GB and Iran, is meeting in London to decide procedural aspect of case; decision on substance is whether Jamaica, by 7-fold increase in taxes on bauxite in '74, violated valid contract; case is test of Internatl Center for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) estab under auspices of World Bank, which US and Jamaica are signatories of convention along with about 70 other countries; set up procedures for settling recurrent disputes between foreign cos and host countries; Jamaica has declined to participate in proceedings; after passing tax increase in mid-'74, Jamaican Govt notified ICSID that it regarded 'any legal dispute arising directly out of investment relating to minerals or other natural resources' not subject to convention, which prompted protest lr from Edward C Schmults, then gen counsel of Treas, to A Broches, sec gen of ICSID; Schmults says under terms of convention, country could declare some kind of investments exempt from its provisions only by notice in advance; key preliminary decision came last July when tribunal ruled that Kaiser Aluminum & Chem Corp and Alcoa had jurisdiction, despite Jamaica's notice; Jamaica has declined to file any briefs or appt arbitrator in case; complicating factor has been that Kaiser and Reynolds intend to negotiate new agreement with Jamaica if full agreement can be reached and will withdraw complaints in ICSID; Alcoa apparently intends to fight issue to end; question remaining is what will happen if tribunal finds in favor of aluminum cos or just Alcoa and orders monetary compensation (M)
The Libyan Government is preventing 520 non-Libyan employes of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, including 230 Americans, from leaving Libya, the oil company said yesterday.

Occidental Petroleum Corp says Libyan Govt is preventing 520 non-Libyan employes of corp, including 230 Amers, from leaving Libya; says corp made 'special request' to Sec Kissinger and Pres Ford to get visas for its employes; incident is latest in long-standing dispute between Libyan Govt and Occidental over petroleum policy and oil concession agreements; State Dept spokesman Robert Funseth says dept is looking into matter (M)

Moroccan and Algerian troops are lined up along northern Spanish Sahara border ready for confrontation over country; Morocco and Mauritania have lodged territorial claims to Spanish Sahara but Moroccan officials say 2 countries have secret understanding to partition territory if and when Spanish rule ends; Algerian Pres Hourai Boumediene says he backs Spanish proposal for referendum in which 60,000 nomadic inhabitants will be allowed to choose independence; Moroccan Govt has warned that it will not tolerate such a referendum in territory it regards as having been subject to Moroccan rulers for at least 5 centuries; map (M)

Occidental Petroleum Corp repts talks in NY with Libyan Govt have been broken off without any progress; says differences will have to be resolved by arbitration proceedings it has already brought with internatl cts of arbitration in The Hague and in France; Occidental withholds $440-million in back payments to Libya while awaiting verdict on its $1-billion damage suits against Govt; Libya bars 520 non-Libyan co employes, including 230 Amers, from leaving nation, apparently in retaliation for suits (S)

UN group has recommended that UN Gen Assembly act to enable people of Spanish Sahara to decide own future through consultation under UN auspices; recommendation has stopped short of asking referendum for area; Spain, which controls territory, has postponed referendum on Sahara's future to give Internatl Ct of Justice time to make recommendation to Gen Assembly; Spain's major adversaries in dispute are Morocco and Mauritania, which claim area by historic rights; World Ct is trying to decide whether Sahara was unclaimed land at time Spain colonized it, or whether it had legal ties to Morocco and area now called Mauritania (M)

MARRAKESH, Morocco, Oct. 16 King Hassan II announced today that he would soon lead a march of 350,000 unarmed Moroccans, more than 30,000 of them women, into the Spanish Sahara to claim that territory for Morocco.

Moroccan King Hassan II announces that he soon will lead march of 350,000 unarmed Moroccans into Spanish Sahara to claim territory for Morocco, broadcast; announcement follows declaration by Internatl Ct of Justice that it cannot 'establish any tie of territorial sovereignty' over Spanish Sahara either for Morocco or Mauritania; Hassan warns Algerian Govt, which has refused to back Morocco's claims to Sahara, that it should not interfere; proposal for referendum is believed to have backing of majority in UN; march appears to be way of heading off such vote, which Moroccans feel will go against them; map (M)

Moroccans flock to recruiting stations in response to call by King Hassan II for march of 350,000 unarmed people to take over Spanish Sahara; march to claim territory, which Spain is preparing to relinquish, was announced by Hassan hrs after Internatl Ct of Justice had ruled that both Morocco and Mauritania had some ties to tribes in area when it became Spanish colony in 1884; ruling, which was non-binding consultative opinion requested by UN Gen Assembly, also says that ct cannot 'establish any tie of territorial sovereignty' over disputed territory for either of 2 countries; Spain is committed to self-determination for 75,000 people who live in Sahara, and with wide backing for this in UN, diplomatic efforts are expected to be made in world orgn to block Moroccan march; projected march is believed to be aimed at heading off any referendum in Sahara since official feeling is that any such vote will be bound to go against Morocco; there has been increasing anger in Morocco against Algeria because of support for idea of self-determination; Hassan has said that marchers will take measures of 'self-defense' if forces 'other than' Spanish get in way; referenence is believed to be to Algeria; map (L)

Morocco has brushed aside Spanish protests and is going ahead with plans for peaceful march by 350,000 volunteers led by King Hassan II into Spanish Sahara to back Morocco's claim to northwest African territory; Spanish Saharan groups Natl Union party and Algerian-backed Polisario Front say followers will mass along northern border to block march; Moroccan officials apparently are hoping for some Western support in emergency UN Security Council session, due to meet on Oct 20 at Spain's request; Moroccan Information Min Ahmed Taibi Benhima has issued communique denouncing Spanish request for meeting; illus (L)

Spain UN Amb Jaime de Pinies has called on UN Security Council to appeal urgently to Morocco to refrain from carrying out planned march by 350,000 civilians into disputed Spanish Sahara territory; Moroccan King Hassan II has brushed aside Spain's protests and insists he will lead peaceful march by volunteers into Sahara to back up Morocco's claim to region; diplomatic sources say there is growing concern that group in Spanish Sahara known as Polisario Front will organize followers to block Moroccan march into Sahara; front is believed to draw support and weapons from Algerian sources; Algeria has served notice that it wants to participate in Council's debate; Morocco UN Amb Driss Slaoui comments (L)

Occidental Petroleum Corp says that its 520 non-Libyan employes and their families, including 230 Amers, have been told that they can leave Libya providing that they are replaced; employes have been prohibited from leaving Libya as part of dispute between Libya and Occidental; David B Orser, pres of co's internatl operations, says 20 employes have left country under replacement terms (M)

ed scores King Hassan II's lack of statesmanship that it feels should accompany Morocco's claims to Spanish Sahara; notes Hassan's motives; says he rightly fears referendum of Spanish Sahara's 75,000 residents would go against union with Morocco; says 'liberation front' favoring independence and probably backed by Algeria and Libya appears to command more popular support than either of 2 client parties sponsored by Spain and Morocco; says referendum under internatl supervision is least undesirable way to resolve issue

Mobil Oil Corp repts net income fell to $231.1-million in '75 3d qr from $277.8-million in '74 qr; repts profits fell 32.2% to $613-million in '75 1st 9 mos from $903.8-million in '74 period; says 9-mo revenues totaled $16.48-billion, compared with $14.97-billion in '74 period; Mobil chmn Rawleigh Warner Jr comments (I)

REYKJAVIK, Iceland Gudmundur Kjaernested is a folk hero among the 220,000 inhabitants of this remote island republic of glaciers, volcanoes and earthquakes. He is captain of the Tyr, the biggest of the Icelandic Coast Guard's six patrol vessels. Armed with a 57-millimeter gun that he said was made in 1895, and "a little pistol for boarding parties," Captain Kjaernested is fighting the British, and he is widely thought here to be winning.

former Brit Aviation Min Julian Amery says in '64 US came close to forcing halt in development of plane; says members of Kennedy and Johnson Adm brought heavy pressure on GB to abandon plane, and that Amer officials may have threatened to deny GB needed loans if project went ahead; allegations are contained in book by Brit Aircraft Corp dir Geoffrey Knight, entitled Concorde: The Inside Story; Knight and Amery attribute Amer opposition to fears of Concorde's competitive impact on US aerospace indus, which at time lagged behind GB, France and USSR in development of supersonic passenger aircraft; Prime Min James Callaghan, former Chancellor of the Exchequer, says there is 'absolutely no truth' to allegations; Amery illus (M)
Madrid's Jewish community spokesman says that Spanish Queen Sofia has chosen synagogue as site for 1st public speech; Sofia will appear with Rabbi Baruj Garzon; King Juan Carlos will not attend (S)

Ramsey Clark yesterday urged the enactment of a Federal law to bar bribery by American corporations, charging that the practice had "strained American relations with friendly nations, undermined the free market system and corrupted domestic policymaking."
Marvin Kitman lr to Queen Elizabeth II lists advantages to countries if GB would take on US as colony again at time of US Tricentennial (L)

S African police gunfire that stemmed recent rioting in Pretoria and Johannesburg areas has reverberated sharply hundreds of miles away in Transkei, 1st of S Africa's black 'homelands' to accept statehood; delay in territory's independence, originally set for Oct 26, seems more probable as result of hardened positions that S African and Transkei govts have adopted in dispute that already was bitter before rioting; any postponement will be blow to Vorster's prestige; map (L)

With luck, the Turkish, research ship Sismik I will complete its seismic studies in the Aegean Sea without provoking a military confrontation between Greece and Turkey. An informal understanding has evidently been reached by the two governments, under pressure from their NATO allies, that will allow the vessel to carry out modest explorations even in disputed waters without precipitating the clash both sides have been threatening ever since the Sismik's voyage was projected.

Greek Foreign Min Dimitrios Bitsios, in Aug 12 meeting of UN Security Council, accuses Turkey of 'provocative acts' in Aegean Sea; Turkish Foreign Min Ihsan Sabri Caglayangil will reply on Aug 13; both mins will meet separately with Sec Kissinger on Aug 14; Greek and Turkish claims to Aegean mineral rights revd (M)

But the high court criticized Israeli military authorities in the occupied West Bank, suggesting that they had bypassed legal procedure by moving with excessive haste, and recommended that Mayor Fahad Kawasmeh of Hebron and Mohammed Milhem of Halhul be allowed to appeal their banishment before an established military review panel.

To the Editor: The United Nations Security Council's action in censuring Israel over the Jerusalem declaration which considers it to be that nation's capital, illustrates, apart from the patent political motivation behind the resolution, the utter inability or unwillingness of that body to deal with the more urgent priority problems that confront the international community. A glaring case in point is the hostage situation in Iran.

They are also a symbol of our daily commitment of conscience to the objective of achieving their release.''

Judge Richard Reeve Baxter of the International Court of Justice at The Hague died of cancer yesterday at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston. He was 59 years old. Judge Baxter, who lived in Cambridge, Mass., was also the Manley Hudson professor of law at Harvard. As a judge on the World Court, he was concerned with a variety of causes, ranging from international humanitarian law to the regulation of marine resources.

Guess who's coming to the United Nations to preach the sanctity of treaties and the inviolability of national territory? One has to admire the cheek of Prime Minister Mohammed Ali Rajai, who will today plead Iran's case against Iraqi aggression before the Security Council. A prize for diplomatic impertinence - the Khomeini Cup? - should go by unanimous vote to the Islamic Republic of Iran. It's been nearly a year since a mob stormed the United States Embassy in Teheran and had the act condoned, if not encouraged, by the leaders of the Iranian revolution. And for nearly a year, Iran has ignored all appeals for the release of the American diplomats, whose imprisonment violates the Vienna Convention, the precepts of Islam and the universal and ancient diplomatic necessities of civilization. That same Security Council in which Iran now seeks justice has three times unanimously condemned the hostage-taking. Its judgment was sustained - also unanimously - by the International Court of Justice at The Hague. Not a single government has supported Iran's act of abduction and, yes, aggression. That aggression has brought Iran no benefit; as the difficulty of now turning to the United Nations shows, it left Iran helpless and isolated when Iraq attacked a month ago.

West Africa, Dec. 25 - Can an African territory, with a population that is predominantly black, find independence and happiness under the leadership of a white Afrikaans-speaking farmer? The question is raised by the case of Dirk Mudge, who last July became chairman of the Council of Ministers of this vast war-ridden land and thus the nominal head of a government that is still basically run by South African civil servants.

Iran's release of the documented American responses to its conditions for freeing the 52 hostages is yet another baffling turn in the maneuvers by Prime Minister Mohammed Ali Rajai and other members of his political faction to find a way out of the hostage crisis. Iran's purpose in making the documents public was not immediately clear. Last night, Prime Minister Rajai summoned the heads of all diplomatic missions in Teheran and local and foreign journalists to an extraordinary session in the Foreign Ministry's ornate reception room. He proposed that the United States return the money that it could agree belonged to Iran while the hostages would remain captive until disputed claims had been settled through arbitration.

By Hans Smit To the Editor: Now that the present Administration's efforts to resolve the Iranian hostage-taking appear to have led to their predictable results, it seems an appropriate time for reflection on the course next to be taken. At the beginning of the crisis, two approaches were possible. The United States could have insisted on Iran's complying with its clear treaty obligations and international law by demanding the surrender of the hostages and by refusing to make any financial concessions to Iran. Or the United States could have taken a more flexible position and have sought to negotiate.

Asked recently about the chances for an agreement at the conference here on South-West Africa, the nation to be known as Namibia, a South African Cabinet Minister replied that he was pessimistic. ''Do you think,'' he inquired, ''that it is possible to satisfy all the demands of Sam Nujoma?'' In fact, one of the striking features of the conference so far is that Mr. Nujoma, the leader of the insurgent movement known as the South-West Africa People's Organization, has made no demands whatsoever. In his one public statement, he simply declared - in a manner that his own spokesman, at least, could later call ''statesmanlike'' and that diplomats described as a refreshing change from his performance at previous meetings - that he was ready to sign a cease-fire now to end the guerrilla war on the disputed territory's northern border and start the transition to independence. So far the flow of demands and polemics has been almost entirely one-way, coming from political parties functioning inside the territory that have been seated here, against their own strenuous objections, as members of the official South African delegation. Some of these parties could marshal support in an election campaign but others have little more than a paper existence.

Stephen M. Schwebel, Deputy Legal Adviser at the State Department, and Abdullah Fikri al-Khani, Syria's Ambassador to India, were elected by the General Assembly today to be judges on the International Court of Justice. Mr. Schwebel, a 51-year-old expert on international law and the youngest American ever elected to the court, will fill the uncompleted term of Judge Richard R. Baxter, who died last September.

The United States and Iran reached formal agreement early this morning on the terms for releasing the 52 American hostages and returning to Iran billions of dollars of its assets frozen by American authorities. The agreement was signed in Algiers by Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher on behalf of the United States. Behzad Nabavi, the chief Iranian negotiator, had signed it earlier in Teheran. President Carter planned to fly to West Germany later today to be on hand when the hostages are flown there, with a stop in Algeria, after being released by Iran, presumably today. Medical Examinations Planned Algerian transport planes flew to Teheran to pick up the hostages, and a team of Algerian doctors left their hotel in Teheran to examine the Americans before their departure.

Under the agreement with Iran on freeing the hostages, President Carter must take several steps to fulfill the American side of the accord. The steps include the signing of these executive orders and declarations: - A declaration that the policy of the United States is to refrain from interfering in the internal affairs of Iran. - An order freeing all Iranian assets in the United States and in the hands of American banks and companies abroad, which the President froze on Nov. 14, 1979.

Not since Pearl Harbor had the nation been so humiliated. Several dozen of its diplomats and servicemen were held captive for more than a year in a far-away land by a seemingly irrational mob led by an aged Islamic ascetic, and Americans, from President Carter on down, were powerless to act. The President tried pleading, tried bargaining, tried threatening and, in one instance, tried attacking, but it was all in vain. Congress passed a law exempting the hostages from paying income taxes but could do no more. Individual citizens, equally frustrated and eager to make some gesture of support, recalled a once-popular song about a convict coming home and tied yellow ribbons around the trees in their front yards. It was not just those in the embassy in Teheran who were captive. It was, as they said night after night on television, ''America Held Hostage.''

Following, as made public by the State Department today, are the texts of two documents signed by Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher in Algiers this morning. The first outlines the commitments undertaken by Iran and the United States in connection with the release of the hostages; the second concerns the settlement of claims. Declaration The Government of the Democratic and Popular Republic of Algeria, having been requested by the Governments of the Islamic Republic of Iran and the United States of America to serve as an intermediary in seeking a mutually acceptable resolution of the crisis in their relations arising out of the detention of the 52 United States nationals in Iran, has consulted extensively with the two Governments as to the commitments which each is willing to make in order to resolve the crisis within the framework of the points stated in the resolution of Nov. 2, 1980, of the Islamic Consultative Assembly of Iran.

The Carter Administration has agreed to return to Iran immediately less than half of the $8 billion to $10 billion in frozen Iranian assets in exchange for the 52 American hostages, according to agreements made public today and to banking sources. The United States promised to refer some private American claims to binding international arbitration and apparently agreed to nullify some other claims. The Administration also agreed to give Iran what could possibly be decisive support in its lawsuits to recover any property of the late Shah and his close relatives that may still be in the United States. But crucial portions of the agreements were kept a closely guarded secret today as unexpected problems developed in resolving Iran's disputes with large banks that hold most of the frozen assets. These problems centered on a secret 11-page appendix that, according to Behzad Nabavi, Iran's chief negotiator, was delivered to him today hours after the hostage accord had been signed. Mr. Nabavi said the appendix was an ''underhanded maneuver for delaying the final solution to the problem.''

Following are important developments in the hostage crisis from the embassy seizure to the present: Nov. 4, 1979 - Iranian militants seize the United States Embassy and take 66 Americans hostage, demanding that the United States send the deposed Shah back to Iran. Nov. 9 - The United Nations Security Council calls on the militants to release the hostages. Nov. 12 - President Carter orders a halt to oil imports from Iran. Nov. 14 - President Carter freezes all Iranian assets in the United States. Nov. 19-20 - Thirteen hostages, five women and eight black men, are released. Dec. 4 - The United Nations Security Council votes unanimously to urge Iran to free the hostages. Dec. 12 - The United States State Department orders the expulsion of 183 Iranian diplomats. Dec. 15 - The Shah flies to what is called temporary exile in Panama and the International Court of Justice orders Iran to free the hostages. Jan. 1, 1980 - Secretary General Kurt Waldheim arrives in Iran. Jan. 13 - The Security Council votes to impose sanctions against Iran but the Soviet Union vetoes the resolution. Jan. 25 - Abolhassan Bani-Sadr is elected President of Iran. Jan. 29 - It is disclosed that the Canadian Embassy in Teheran spirited six Americans out of Iran. Feb. 20 - Secretary General Waldheim announces formation of a United Nations commission. March 11 - The United Nations commission leaves Iran without reporting on its investigation. March 23 - The Shah flies to Egypt to have his spleen removed. April 7 - The United States breaks diplomatic relations with Iran and imposes economic sanctions.

A group of a hundred companies that have tied up more than $1 billion in Iranian assets in lawsuits in Federal courts in New York urged President Reagan today to delay enforcing President Carter's executive orders under the hostage agreement, ''including those compelling turnover of Iranian assets.'' They cited ''serious constitutional and other legal questions.'' Reagan Administration officials said today that the President fully intended to carry out the commitments of the accord, although he wanted to study the provisions carefully. The officials did not address the question of how soon they might be carried out. A State Department spokesman said he could not comment on timing. Those pressing for a delay included such major corporations as Xerox, Brown & Root, Ingersoll-Rand Company, and Halliburton Company. Other claimants have gone to Federal courts in Washington to try to stop movement of other portions of the $3 to $4 billion of Iranian assets remaining in the United States.

To the Editor: Following the rejoicing over the return of the hostages, there must come a sober assessment of the price paid. Throughout the crisis, the Carter Administration stressed that it would agree only to a settlement compatible with our national honor. The term ''honor'' is sufficiently vague to leave ample room for differences of judgment. Nevertheless, the national honor would appear compromised if the settlement departs from basic rules of fair, principled and constitutional conduct. Measured by that standard, the settlement reached appears not honorable in various respects.$ More recently, the Carter Administration asserted that the settlement merely undoes the measures taken in response to the seizure of the hostages. This assertion is inaccurate. Indeed, the settlement appears improper and substantially to reward Iran for its illegal conduct in at least three respects: * The United States gives up all claims, both its own and those of the hostages, arising from the seizure of the hostages and the embassy.

Iran appeared so eager to resolve the hostage crisis last September that it alerted Washington ahead of time to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's statement outlining for the first time Iran's four conditions for releasing the hostages. In his most extensive discussion of the details that led to last week's agreement freeing the 52 Americans, the chief negotiator, Warren M. Christopher, disclosed that Iran sent an advance copy of the four points to insure that Washington would send a representative to a secret rendezvous in Bonn with Sadegh Tabatabai, the grandson of Ayatollah Khomeini. These other points emerged from the interview with Mr. Christopher and from talks with other officials: - The basic American negotiating position on resolving the hostage crisis was set in early September and did not change perceptibly throughout the negotiations. - Iran continually scaled down its financial demands to reach the accord. Initially it sought $14 billion in frozen assets; then it asked for $9.5 billion; then $8.1 billion, and finally it accepted $7.9 billion, of which less than $3 billion actually went to Iran. The rest was used to pay off American and foreign bank creditors.

As the national celebration over the safe return of the 52 Americans held hostage by Iran draws to a close, the debate over whether to revoke or honor the complex agreements that led to their release may only be beginning. Some members of Congress, lawyers for many of the more than 350 companies and individuals that have sued Iran, and publications as diverse as The Wall Street Journal and The New Republic have asserted that President Reagan could and perhaps should renounce as extortionate and illegal all or part of the dollars-for-hostages deal negotiated with Iran by the Carter Administration through Algerian intermediaries. Several claimants have gone to court to challenge the constitutionality of efforts to transfer out of the country Iranian assets against which they have filed claims and to terminate their lawsuits in favor of the international arbitration provided in the agreements. Appeals From Carter Aides On the other hand, several former senior officials of the Carter Administration have urged their successors to scrupulously enforce the agreements, which they say are highly favorable to the United States and to Americans with commercial claims against Iran. President Reagan, at his first news conference, said yesterday that ''I think that the United States will honor the obligations'' under the accords, but he said Administration lawyers had not yet determined ''whether they are in keeping with international and national or our own laws.''

To the Editor: It is significant that Mr. Kalangula and Mr. Mudge of the Democratic Turnhalle Alliance (''Lopsided United Nations Position on Namibia,'' letter Feb. 1) were compelled, in defense of their position at the United Nations Geneva meeting on Namibia, to make a statement they know to be untrue, namely that the U.N. ''paid Swapo's travel expenses to Geneva and picked up the tab for its accommodation there.'' he United Nations did not pay for Swapo - the South-West Africa People's Organization - or any other delegation at Geneva. Messrs. Kalangula and Mudge know this perfectly well and, very wisely, did not therefore raise this issue publicly at Geneva.

Mahomed Ali Currim Chagla, an Indian jurist and statesman who served as his country's Foreign Minister and Ambassador to the United States, died of a heart attack yesterday, his family reported in Bombay. He was 80 years old.

A senior Greek official spoke glowingly of the improved atmosphere of the current Greek-Turkish talks, referred to his many Turkish friends and served a visitor Turkish coffee, then settled down to discuss ''the Turkish threat'' at length. The governing circles in Athens appear to have a firm desire to reach an accommodation with Turkey on basic, longstanding problems, but this is overshadowed by a profound distrust of Turkish intent. In both Government offices and political quarters, Greeks repeatedly inquire why the Turks have set up an Aegean army outside the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and why there is a large Turkish landing fleet in the Gulf of Izmir. Asked about Greece's relations with the Turks, politicians produce a collection of statements by Turkish leaders to demonstrate ''expansionist'' ambitions.

Former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit wrote a poem about Turks and Greeks more than 30 years ago, and this passage from it still holds true: We've sworn at each other, We've drawn knives like enemies, Yet a love lies hidden in us For days of peace. By and large Turks are tired of disputes with Greeks and would like to put an end to them, if this could be done while preserving the national honor. But there is no evidence in Turkey of the kind of obsession found in Greece over a ''threat'' from Ankara. For the average Turk, unlike his Greek counterpart, the problems between the two countries are more of a nuisance than a danger.

A high civil court ruled today that the West German Government was not under a legal obligation to obtain the release of Rudolf Hess, Adolf Hitler's onetime deputy, who is serving a life term in Spandau Prison. Appeals by the United States, Britain and France as well as West Germany to have the prisoner, now 87 years old, released on humanitarian grounds have been blocked by the Soviet Union, which regards Hess as a symbol of Nazism and is determined not to allow his release.

President Reagan said today that he had asked the Senate to ratify an East Coast boundary treaty with Canada but that he had at the same time asked it to drop consideration of a proposed fisheries agreement. The fisheries agreement would establish limits on catches for various species of fish and shellfish, limits that United States fishermen opposed. The draft treaty, covering both the boundary and fisheries questions, has been held up in Congress since it was signed and submitted for ratification by President Jimmy Carter two years ago.

President Reagan likes to tell stories and Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau likes to listen to them. The fact that, according to all reports, the two men enjoyed each other's company, despite their different backgrounds and philosophies, appeared to be one explanation for the satisfaction that both expressed today at the end of the President's visit to Canada. The Canadians were all the more satisfied because they had received some signals from Washington in the days before the visit that had worried and even angered them. In contrast, they heard so many expressions of good will and good intentions while the Americans were here that almost every high Canadian official who was questioned this morning said how happy he was with the outcome.
The Foreign Relations Committee approved a 1979 boundary treaty with Canada today and sent it to the Senate.

The United States has authorized the withdrawal of its claim in the International Court of Justice for damages from Iran for its 444-day holding of the American hostages, sources close to the case said today. The formal withdrawal of the claim next week will state, however, that the United States can reopen the case if Iran ''fails to live up to its commitments,'' the sources said.

South Africa can be expected to embrace the Reagan Administration's effort to revise a Western proposal for settlement of the dispute over the territory of South-West Africa, a senior official indicated today. The main point of the revision would be to seek agreement on a constitution for the territory, also known as Namibia, before an election held under international supervision that would pave the way to independence. Under the existing proposal put forward by five Western nations, including the United States, the election under international supervision would be for a constituent assembly that would then draft the constitution. Thus the losers of the election would run the risk of also losing their opportunity to make sure their rights were constitutionally protected.
The United States asked the International Court of Justice today to dismiss the American claim against Iran for damages resulting from the seizing and holding of American hostages.

The Senate voted 91 to 0 today to approve a treaty with Canada under which a panel of international judges would be asked to settle a dispute over maritime boundaries in the Gulf of Maine. The treaty had originally been coupled with a United States-Canadian fisheries treaty that had been bitterly opposed by New England senators who contended that it would injure American interests in the rich Georges Bank and Gulf of Maine fishing grounds.

To the Editor: One of the chief weaknesses of the United Nations is its inability to enforce its reolutions even when those resolutions are backed by decisions of the International Court of Justice. The reason for this helplessness is what many nations at the U.N. call an ''abuse of the veto power.'' An abuse of the veto power occurred last year in the case of the 52 Americans who were held hostage in Iran. The Security Council adopted a resolution requesting the release of the American hostages. This resolution was backed by a unanimous decision of the International Court of Justice. But sanctions to enforce that decision against Iran were vetoed by the Soviet Union.

To the Editor: In his letter printed May 11, Walter Hoffmann argues that the great-power veto of United Nations Security Council resolutions blocks the enforcement of International Court of Justice decisions by blocking sanctions that can be legally imposed only by unvetoed Security Council resolutions. He is wrong on several counts. he Soviet Union never blocked enforcement of a World Court decision during the hostage crisis by vetoing sanctions against Iran. The Court's interim order, which we sought to have enforced by economic sanctions, was not a decision within the terms of the U.N. Charter; by the time the Court produced its decision, we had acted in contempt of the legal process by our misconceived rescue mission, and we never did complete the legal steps provided in the Charter for enforcement of decisions.

Mr. and Mrs. Cochran B. Supplee of New York and Wassaic, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Angela Turner Supplee, to Don Francis Chesser, son of Mrs. Ermel F. Chesser of Athens, Ohio, and the late Mr. Chesser. A September wedding is planned.

The Economic and Social Council, dedicated to the advancement of economic and social progress for the peoples of the world and one of the six principal organs of the United Nations, is the subject of the concluding issue of this year from that world organization. Six commemoratives are being issued on Nov. 21 - two in United States currency for use at the New York headquarters of the U.N., two in Swiss currency for use at the European headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland, and two in Austrian currency for use at auxiliary offices of the U.N. at Vienna, Austria. The ''hottest'' artist in Europe today, Friedrich Hundertwasser of Austria, has contributed a painting for the cacheted covers traditionally put out by the World Federation of United Nations Associations to accompany new U.N. issues. Three different designs have been created for the six commemoratives, all multicolors. The denominations are 15 and 20 cents, 40 and 70 Swiss centimes and 4 and 6 Austrian schillngs. The U.S. equivalents of the Swiss values are 25 and 44 cents, and of the Austrian values 33 and 49 cents, subject to exchange rate fluctuation.

Forty people who identified themselves as Libyan students opposed to the regime of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi took over offices of Libya's United Nations mission yesterday for three hours. They were arrested after six New York City police officers broke down a back door with a battering ram. The demonstrators ousted 20 to 30 Libyans from the second-floor office at 866 United Nations Plaza, at East 48th Street, shortly after 11 A.M. They took no hostages, made no demands and offered no resistance when the police finally entered.

Sir Humphrey Waldock, president of the International Court of Justice, has died here of a heart attack, the court announced today. He was 77 years old. As head of the court, Sir Humphrey presided over the United States case against Iran that resulted in a May 1980 order to free the American hostages. Iran ignored the ruling. The United States later withdrew its claim when the seizure was settled in direct negotiations.

To the Editor: It is surprising that debate over the Reagan Administration's decision to hold naval maneuvers in the Gulf of Sidra - which led to the confrontation between American and Libyan jets -has ignored a highly relevant International Court of Justice case. he ''Fisheries'' case (1951 I.C.J. Reports 116) involved a dispute between Great Britain and Norway over the issue argued by the U.S. and Libya: When there is a major indentation in a coastline, does the boundary between national and international waters follow the coastline, or is it measured from a base drawn between the outermost points of the indentation?

To the Editor: In deploring the escalation of the violence in Namibia's quest for freedom by the South African army's invasion of Angola, Dean Fischer, U.S. State Department spokesman, said the fighting ''must be understood in its full context.'' Mr. Fischer sketched a very limited context, which laid blame primarily on Namibian guerrillas who are fighting for their country's independence and on the presence of Cuban troops in Angola. He did add, however, that ''South Africa's resistance to granting Namibia independence, and cross-border raids such as this one are an element of the broader problem.''

To the Editor: In his Sept. 1 letter, Representative Bill Green compared the 1951 fisheries case before the International Court of Justice to the recent dispute between the United States and Libya in the Gulf of Sidra. By citing a part of the Court's decision - that Great Britain had lost its right to object to Norwegian maritime claims because it had failed to oppose them in an active fashion - he concludes that the ''United States could not indefinitely have failed to challenge the Libyan claim . . . without losing rights to the water.'' It is clear, though, that the United States has rigorously opposed Libyan claims over both the Gulf of Sidra and the so-called ''restricted area'' of 100 nautical miles around Tripoli since they were asserted in 1973.

Five jurists - representatives of Britain, France, India, Senegal and Argentina - were elected to nineyear terms today on the International Court of Justice, the judicial arm of the United Nations. Nagendra Singh of India easily won re-election, defeating Anwarul S. Haq of Pakistan.
Judge Abdullah Ali el-Erian, an Egyptian diplomat and a member of the International Court of Justice, died of a heart attack Saturday, a spokesman for the Court announced Monday. He was 60 years old.

Japan, Spa in and Ireland are draftinga compromise resolution that proposes voluntary sanctions against Israel for an nexing the Golan Heights, Western diplomats said today. The three Security Council members hope to come up with a formula that would both satisfy Syria and avoid a veto by the United States. Their prospects, envoys here said, are not rated highly.

The 15-member International Court of Justice today elected Taslim Olawale Elias of Nigeria to be its president. Judge Elias, 67 years old, had been acting president and succeeds Sir Humphrey Waldock of Britain, who died in August.
