To the Editor: I am surprised that in all the discussions concerning the Falkland Islands crisis I have heard no mention of submitting the question of ownership to the International Court of Justice at The Hague.

Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, in a speech before the Senate concerning a resolution of the Falkland Island crisis, April 13, 1982: The invasion by the Argentine military of the Falkland Islands is the first occasion since the establishment of NATO in 1948 that nationals of a NATO member have been subjected to military occupation by another power. This demands the greatest attention of our nation, as well as the other members of the alliance. To say that the U.N. Security Council was emphatic in its denunciation of the Argentine action is not at all to say that the issue of the sovereignty of the Falkland Islands is not a matter of dispute. Title to the islands is clearly disputed. International courts, when dealing with disputed claims, do not look for the perfect title. The courts will simply seek the party with the better title.

To the Editor: Among all the ideas put forward concerning the Falkland Islands negotiations, I have see almost no reference to these three possible means of resolving the dispute: Either Argentina or Britain buy the other's claims. * Refer the dispute to the International Court of Justice.

To the Editor: It is not surprising that Morris Amchan (letter April 15) has heard no mention of submitting the Falklands dispute to the International Court of Justice. Britain has repeatedly offered to refer the matter to the court, and Argentina has consistently declined - predictably, in view of the flimsiness of its claims.

The Organization of American States gave final approval today to a resolution supporting Argentina's claim to sovereignty over the Falkland Islands. The measure also called on Argentina and Britain to agree to a truce and withdraw their forces from the area. The resolution, hailed as a victory by Argentina for its position on the sovereignty issue, also urged an end to the economic sanctions imposed on Argentina by Britain and several of its allies. Agreement was reached just after 2 A.M. at the end of an eighthour, closed-door meeting in search of a resolution acceptable to the O.A.S. delegates. At least two-thirds of the signers of the 1947 Inter-American Treaty of Reciprocal Assistance, a collective security pact usually called the Rio Treaty, were needed to pass the measure.

International Argentina warned Britain that any British ship or plane within 200 miles of the Falklands would be regarded as hostile and dealt with ''accordingly.'' The announcement came a half day before today's scheduled start of a British sea and air blockade of the same area. (Page A1, Column 1.) Argentina holds the key to peace in the Falklands, according to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher who spoke in an emergency debate in Britain's House of Commons. She rejected demands by the opposition that Britain turn to the United Nations or the International Court of Justice in an 11th-hour effort to avert a war. (A9:1-4.)

Following are excerpts from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's speech today in the House of Commons: The Government has taken every possible step that had a reasonable prospect of helping us to achieve our objectives - the withdrawal of the Argentine forces and the end of their illegal occupation of the islands; the restoration of British administration, and a long-term solution which is acceptable not only to the House but to the inhabitants of the Falkland Islands. It is the Government's most earnest hope that we can achieve these objectives by a negotiated settlement. But as the House knows, the Government has taken military measures as well to strengthen our diplomatic efforts. Mr. Haig's initiative would never have got under way if the British Government had not sent the naval task force to the South Atlantic within four days of Argentina's aggression against the Falkland Islands. Gentle Persuasion Unheeded What incentive would there have been for the Argentine junta to give Mr. Haig's ideas more than the most cursory glance if Britain had not underpinned its search for a diplomatic settlement with the dispatch of the task force? Gentle persuasion is not going to make the Argentine Government give up what it has seized by force.

Argentina's military junta said tonight that any British ship or plane found within 200 miles of the Falklands would be regarded as hostile and dealt with ''accordingly.'' The announcement, which said the measure was effective at once, was in response to Britain's declaration of a sea and air blockade of the islands beginning at 7 A.M. Friday, New York time. Much of the British battle fleet was already believed to be within the 200-mile zone. Some reports placed it about 100 miles northeast of Stanley, the capital of the Falklands. It was not immediately clear whether Argentina was planning to try to enforce its declaration.

With the dispute over the Falkland Islands about to enter its most dangerous phase, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher asserted today that ''the key to peace is in the hands of the Argentine Government.'' In an emergency debate in the House of Commons, the fourth since Argentina occupied the islands on April 2, Mrs. Thatcher affirmed the view that ''gentle persuasion is not going to make the Argentine Government give up what it has seized by force.'' She rejected, for the moment at least, demands from the opposition that she turn to the United Nations or to the International Court of Justice in a last-ditch attempt to avoid war. About an hour after the debate ended, a rejoinder came from Argentina with the announcement that it planned to treat as hostile British ships and planes that approached the mainland, the Falklands or South Georgia. The Foreign Office said it had no immediate comment, but the announcement appeared to constitute an indirect rejection of diplomatic overtures.

Following are the main provisions of the Law of the Sea Treaty: Territorial Waters - Each nation's sovereign territory extends 12 miles beyond its coast. In this zone, however, all foreign vessels must be allowed the right of innocent passage, that is, passage that does not threaten the nation's security. Free Passage - Beyond 12 miles, all ships and planes, military and commercial, can move freely. Subm@arines can travel under water. Exclusive Economic Zone - Every coastal nation has exclusive rights to the fish and other marine life in the waters extending 200 miles beyond its shores. When nations are separated by a body of water less than 400 miles, they must establish dividing lines for the zones.

Third-world nations adopted a wide-ranging treaty today to govern the use and exploitation of the seas, but the United States was in an isolated group that rejected the code. The vote, ending eight years of diplomatic bargaining, was 130 to 4. Seventeen nations, a combination from the European Economic Community and the Soviet bloc, abstained. The treaty, controlling everything from the free passage of ships and planes to the exploitation of the ocean's wealth of oil, gas, fish and metals, will come into force when it is ratified by 60 nations. But it is unclear how effective it will be without the United States and the possible absence of such industrial nations as West Germany, Britain and the Soviet Union, all of which abstained.

The 1982 World's Fair opened in the historic East Tennessee hills today with a festival flavor of flags and bands and balloons, prayers and pomp, dances, songs, speeches and the special mountain and country music for which the region is renowned. President Reagan and Mrs. Reagan, scores of international diplomats and dignitaries, local politicians, bankers and business executives gathered along an artificial lake for the official opening of the first world's fair ever held in the Southeast, an international exposition that will run for 184 days. Sun-splashed throngs estimated at tens of thousands of people squeezed into other areas far from the opening ceremonies, which were under heavy security by Secret Service agents. Some had arrived at the gates as early as 3 A.M. Most could not see the ceremonies.

Hardy Cross Dillard, a former judge on the International Court of Justice and dean of the University of Virginia School of Law from 1963 to 1968, died Wednesday in Charlottesville, Va. He was 79 years old. As a professor and in various academic positions at the University of Virginia, Mr. Dillard became an institution to generations of law students at the university.

To the Editor: A brief comment on the May 20 letter of Marc Truitt (''Albania Is an Unlikely Target of Soviet Military Aggression''): Mr. Truitt's reference to Greek ''abandonment'' of its claims to Northern Epirus (southern Albania) is inaccurate. No Greek government has ever made any statement that would support such a contention.

The American image-makers hired to save the job of the venerable Prime Minister who has been in office for the last 22 of his 82 years have hurriedly decamped from this Indian Ocean island, apparently to avoid charges that they were ''foreign mercenaries'' recruited by the Central Intelligence Agency. Simultaneously, the Prime Minister's main challenger, who is 45 years younger, seems to have effectively ridiculed a last-minute effort to document accusations that he is a hireling of Libya. Thus this polyglot nation of nearly one million now seems almost certain to accomplish something when it votes on Friday that no other member of the Organization of African Unity has done for a long time, if ever before, and that is to bring off a peaceful change of government at the ballot box. The charges and countercharges of foreign interference have helped to offset the sense of being taken for granted that came with all the think-tank theorizing about the strategic significance of the Indian Ocean and the big American military buildup on Diego Garcia, a British-owned island that Mauritius claims as part of its birthright as an independent nation.

As far as the Defense Department in Washington is concerned, the elaborate and costly military staging area that it has built in the Indian Ocean on the tiny island of Diego Garcia, about 1,200 miles from here, is held under the terms of an ironclad lease that will not expire until 2025. As far as the new leftist Government that was swept to power in Mauritius in last week's election is concerned, Diego Garcia ought to be recognized as Mauritian territory. The new Foreign Minister, Jean-Claude de L'Estrac, said as the landslide results poured in that Mauritius would soon seek to open talks on the subject. It is foreseeable that the United States will beg off on the ground that it is only the tenant and cannot speak for the landlord. The landlord is Britain, which once administered Mauritius and Diego Garcia, in the Chagos Archipelago, as if they were parts of a single territory.

West Germany said today that it had begun talks with the United States in an effort to get it to reverse its decision to widen restrictions on the use of American-developed equipment in a projected natural gas pipeline between Western Europe and the Soviet Union. The Government spokesman, Klaus Bolling, said that West Germany was not ruling out the option of taking the matter before the International Court of Justice in The Hague. Mr. Bolling characterized the Government's reaction to the Reagan Administration's announcement as one of ''concern'' and ''dismay.'' And he described the decision as ''a contradiction to what was agreed on and discussed at the world economic summit meeting'' earlier this month.

While officials of South Korea and Japan were negotiating a major aid package for Seoul this week, the chairman of the Dow Chemical Company, the largest foreign corporate investor in South Korea, warned during a visit here that uncertain economic and political conditions in South Korea make new investments there seem unattractive for the near future. ''These are difficult days in South Korea,'' said Robert W. Lundeen, Dow's chairman, adding that he would advise other companies considering investing in South Korea ''to weigh the risk-reward equation very carefully'' first. Mr. Lundeen described himself as basically a ''Korea booster,'' and he expressed confidence that Dow's difficulties in South Korea would be resolved and that the country's economy would pick up eventually. ''But we're not interested in investing 5 more cents in Korea until the present problems are straightened out,'' he declared.

''We really have a small United Nations here,'' Dr. Armand Hammer said today at the closing session of a conference on peace and human rights at the Franklin D. Roosevelt Library and Museum here. Dr. Hammer, who sponsored the conference and for whom it was named, was speaking here to 51 delegates from 32 nations gathered for a three-day meeting on what they could do to foster the aims of the conference. After several years of planning and discussion in preparation for this fifth conference, the delegates voted today to establish an international Academy for Peace and Human Rights. They said it would be the first such organization to approach the problems in a broad and scientific way, perhaps more efficiently than the United Nations.

A longstanding dispute between Libya and Malta over oil-drilling rights in the Mediterranean is headed for a peaceful resolution, United Nations officials said today. The two countries have agreed to let the International Court of Justice at The Hague settle their 10-year-old quarrel and determine the limits of the continental shelf between them.

Norman J. Padelford, a professor of political science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for 30 years and a participant in the drafting of the United Nations charter, died on July 13 in Claremont, Calif., of a stroke suffered last January. He was 78 years old and had lived in Claremont for eight years.

For years the stretch of Massachusetts Avenue that wends its way through Northwest Washington from Dupont Circle to Wisconsin Avenue has been known as Embassy Row. But Washington's steady growth as a world capital has caused a corresponding growth in the number and size of embassies here, so now a new diplomatic complex, known as the International Center, is emerging on upper Connecticut Avenue on a 47-acre tract that at one time was the home of the Federal Bureau of Standards. Eventually, two dozen or so embassies are expected to settle there in close proximity, some of them representing countries that are not the best of friends. Such is the power of diplomacy.

The United States, its European allies and a bevy of private companies involved in selling equipment for the Soviet-European gas pipeline are at a political and legal impasse virtually without precedent and with no end in sight. The United States ordered a French-based subsidiary of an American corporation not to ship compressors for the prospective 3,700-mile pipeline. France ordered the shipment made, and the subsidiary complied last week. In turn, the Reagan Administration forbade any American-controlled company to do business with this subsidiary and with a wholly owned French company also involved in the transaction. This placed the private companies, each following the laws of the land in which it was domiciled, squarely between conflcting sovereign compulsions, and the sovereigns show no signs of giving way.

This place, which looks deceptively like the middle of nowhere, is at the center of a gold rush, an oil find, a uranium expedition, a diamond cache, a manganese mine, a timber trove and an international dispute. Kaieteur, a majestic 741-foot waterfall on the Pataro River, is in the heart of the Essequibo, a 58,000-square-mile swath of dense forest, savannah and rivers that is the United Nations' latest diplomatic headache. Guyana, five-eighths of whose territory is here, says the Essequibo is the key to its future. Venezuela says it is the rightful property of its past, snatched in an unscrupulous arbitration 83 years ago.

Iran's unsuccessful attempt to force a vote in the General Assembly last week on Israel's credentials was motivated by revenge - against its Moslem brothers from Arab countries. This is the view of diplomats here most familiar with Teheran's thinking, although it is denied by Iran's delegate to the United Nations. But according to those close to the event, it followed this course: At a private meeting on Oct. 19 the Arab countries, persuaded by other Moslem nations, agreed to abandon their challenge to Israel's seat in the General Assembly, convinced that it would hurt their cause politically and tactically. Instead they agreed to express a ''collective reservation'' on Israel's legitimacy.

The Government of Iran has the right to sue Princess Ashraf Pahlevi, sister of the late Shah of Iran, for $3 billion in a New York court, a State Supreme Court justice ruled in Manhattan yesterday. The lawsuit, which charged that the Shah and his sister ''diverted to their own use funds and property belonging to the Government and people of Iran,'' was one of four brought by Iran in New York and California against the Shah's estate and his family.

Following are the main provisions of the Law of the Sea Treaty, which was signed yesterday in Montego Bay, Jamaica: Territorial Waters - Each nation's sovereign territory extends 12 miles beyond its coast. In this zone, however, all foreign vessels must be allowed the right of innocent passage, that is, passage that does not threaten the nation's security. Free Passage - Beyond 12 miles, all ships and planes, military and commercial, can move freely. Submarines can travel under water. Exclusive Economic Zone -Every coastal nation has exclusive rights to the fish and other marine life in the waters extending 200 miles beyond its shores. When nations are separated by a body of water less than 400 miles, they must establish dividing lines for the zones.

A major step to govern sea lanes and ocean resources was taken here today when 117 nations signed a treaty codifying law for the seas. The United States and other major industrial nations, such as West Germany and Britain, did not sign. President Reagan has firmly rejected the document, chiefly because of its seabed mining provisions, but the others have not ruled out signing later. Nevertheless, third world delegates at this Caribbean resort loudly applauded the outcome, embraced each other jubilantly and asserted that they had started an effective code.

Nearly a decade ago the nations of the world set out to agree on who could sail where on the oceans and who could mine what under them. Ultimately - and with growing predictability - the debate boiled down to the question of dividing up ''the common heritage of mankind,'' the wealth of minerals on the ocean floor. The 117 nations that signed the resultant treaty last week wanted majority rule. The United States and some of the 45 other holdouts would make it every nation for itself.

President Reagan announced today that the United States would not pay a United Nations assessment of as much as $1 million a year. This is the first time, American legal experts said, that Washington has claimed the right to withhold funds. The disputed funds are Washington's share of the costs of a commission set up under the Law of the Sea Treaty that will design rules to govern the mining of minerals from the deep seas. Mr. Reagan refused to sign the treaty codifying law for the sea because of the mining provisions. In a statement issued from Palm Springs, Calif., Mr. Reagan said the funds ''are destined to finance the very aspects of the Law of the Sea Treaty that are unacceptable to the U.S.'' Moreover, he said, the assessment is ''improper'' and ''not legally binding'' because the rule-making commission is ''distinct from the U.N.'' Challenge to U.N. Seen The United States is now required to pay 25 percent of the United Nations' costs. Western diplomats here said Mr. Reagan's decision poses a fundamental challenge to the United Nations existence and compared it to the refusal by the Soviet Union and France to pay their share for peacekeepers in the Congo in 1960, the year the Belgian colony became independent.

Lebanese reaction to the report by an Israeli commission on the killing of Palestinians at two camps in Beirut in September was muted but there was concern among officials here over possible repercussions on the negotiations on the withdrawal of Israeli and other foreign forces from Lebanon. The Lebanese Prime Minister, Shafik al-Wazzan, said he would let the world judge Israel for the massacres at Sabra and Shatila. Government officials said privately they were worried that the commission's conclusions would upset political life in Israel to such an extent that the United States-sponsored talks under way between Lebanon and Israel since December would be affected. Another round of talks was held today by Lebanese, Israeli and American representatives in Beirut's southern suburb of Khalde.

An emotionally disturbed man who said he was searching for William the Silent, a Prince of Orange who died in 1584, invaded Queen Beatrix's residential palace as she was holding a formal dinner, officials said today. ''He was apprehended as soon as he opened the door to the service quarters of the guest wing,'' a police spokesman said.

Steering a Mediterranean ministate through the shoals of international diplomacy is never easy, as events of recent weeks in Malta again showed. Last month, two mutinous Libyan lieutenants hijacked a plane carrying 158 people and landed in Valetta. Prime Minister Dom Mintoff talked the officers into surrendering, but then he faced the choice of handing them to Col. Muammer el-Qaddafi for likely execution or releasing them and offending the Libyan leader. Last week, he was still thinking about it. On Malta, Libya is no joke. The three-island Maltese archipelago is locked into a geography that justifies the overworked term ''strategic.'' With a population smaller than Staten Island's 352,000 in an area not much larger than the Borough of Queens, it is close to the center of the Mediterranean -midway between Gibraltar and Suez and roughly halfway between Europe and Africa. Its nearest neighbors are the Italian boot and Comiso, Sicily, 60 miles away. Late this year the United States wants to install northeast-aimed cruise missiles in Comiso, barring a deal with Moscow on European nuclear arms levels.

Chad called on the Security Council today to help remove Libyan forces from the northwestern part of its territory. It also accused Libya of ''repeated acts of aggression.'' The sector occupied by Libyan troops, a desert area called the Aouzou Strip, is claimed by Libya under a World War II treaty between Italy and the pro-Axis Vichy Government of France.

The Security Council called on Chad and Libya today to settle their territorial dispute through the Organization of African Unity. The nominal issue before the Council was Chad's complaint that Libyan forces are illegally occupying a section of desert in the northwest, the Aouzou Strip. But according to diplomats here the real concern of the Council was President Hissen Habre's attempt to strengthen his claim as Chad's legitimate ruler. He is opposed by the forces of Goukouni Oueddei, who is supported by Libya.

After two years of seemingly successful negotiations, an intricate treaty between Canada and the United States on the division of west coast salmon catches was suddenly upset by an Alaskan reservation. The document, setting forth principles for joint management of Pacific salmon stocks, had been initialed by both sides and had won approval from the commercial trollers, seiners, Indian tribes, unions and industry representatives serving as advisers to the negotiating committees of both nations. ''For a while we really thought we had a historic breakthrough,'' said Wayne Shinners, the Canadian fisheries official who headed the Canadian effort.

Marc Rich & Company A.G., the Swiss-based commodity trading firm under investigation for possible United States tax evasion, is in a classic double bind. The company cannot give American prosecutors many of the documents they have subpoenaed because the Swiss Government has seized them to make sure their release would not violate the corporate secrecy laws of Switzerland. But every day that goes by without Marc Rich turning over the documents means that it must pay another $50,000 fine because it is in contempt of court in the United States. Some Marc Rich documents, two trunks full, were seized in New York by American authorities.

Although nations have complete control of the airspace over their land and territorial waters, they may shoot down intruders during peacetime under only the most extraordinary circumstances, authorities on international law said yesterday. uf813 Whether the Soviet Union violated international law and custom by shooting down a Korean Air Lines jet, as Secretary of State George P. Shultz said it had, may ultimately depend, however, on facts that are still in dispute - particularly whether the Soviet jets issued warnings to the South Korean plane and whether those warnings were ignored by the Korean pilot. ''Shooting down a civilian passenger plane without warning is clearly contrary to international law,'' said Oliver J. Lissitzyn, professor emeritus of international law and diplomacy at Columbia Law School. ''But if a warning was given to land and the South Koreans disobeyed that order, then the matter becomes much more controversial.''

To the Editor: While there will be much rhetoric at the United Nations over the shooting down by Soviet military forces of the Korean Airlines passenger plane and some retaliatory steps by nations, neither rhetoric nor retaliation will compensate the families for the loss of their loved ones who died in the tragedy. The present statute for the International Court of Justice does not permit private parties to sue a nation in that Court for losses suffered in an international incident. However, both the World Peace Through Law Center and the Campaign for U.N. Reform have proposed that private parties be given access to regional international courts. The U.S. should support such proposals or, at the very least, promote the creation of an International Claims Tribunal.

WASHINGTON DOES anything that deserves the name ''international law'' govern the use of military force? Last week's invasion of Grenada raised the question anew, as Reagan Administration lawyers and critics fenced with citations of treaties and charters, a familiar exchange in any shooting war. The Administration's shifting legal rationale for reconciling the invasion with nonintervention provisions of the United Nations and Organization of American States charters seemed barely plausible to many allies abroad and legal experts at home. House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., in expressing his fears of Administration policy, said the invasion was probably an illegal exercise in ''gunboat diplomacy.'' But not all legal experts saw it as bad policy. Such authorities as Don Wallace Jr., director of the International Law Institute at Georgetown University Law Center, said the episode showed the rules are inadequate. On occasion, he and others argued, good policy may require violating the rules or offering interpretations that bend treaty language. Washington cannot, they said, protect its interests as a great power and still comply with a literal reading of the United Nations Charter in the face of Soviet aggression and subversion, and internal repression by regimes of every stripe. If the Russians ''insist on violating these rules,'' said Prof. Eugene V. Rostow of Yale Law School, ''then pretty soon we're going to start violating them.''

Canadian officials announced this week that they intended to support nine Canadian citizens actively in a long-pending suit against the United States for compensation for being used as unknowing subjects in psychiatric experiments in Montreal 27 years ago. The Central Intelligence Agency secretly paid for the experiments. A week ago a nationwide Canadian television program gave prominence to the seven-year-old legal claims of the plaintiffs and suggested that the Canadian Government had acted timidly. Last Wednesday Foreign Minister Allan J. MacEachen said in Parliament that his office, which until now had agreed to United States requests to keep secret any documents relating to the case, was considering an appeal to the International Court of Justice in behalf of the subjects of the experiments.

To the Editor: J. Lynn Helms, head of the Federal Aviation Agency, writes that the American approach to the Soviet shooting down of a Korean airliner last September has been non-confrontational (letter Jan. 26). He cites as evidence of the success of our approach a resolution, endorsed by the International Civil Aviation Organization Council, that ''deplores'' the incident. But anybody can ''deplore'' what was clearly a deplorable happening. The issue on which the I.C.A.O. was evasive was that of fault. The I.C.A.O. report Mr. Helms mentions attributes the overflight to unintentional pilot error. That is not a condemnation of the Soviet action.

Carlos P. Romulo, the last living signer of the 1945 United Nations Charter, says weaknesses in the document have made it impossible for the organization ''to carry out the purposes for which we intended it.'' Mr. Romulo, who became the first Asian President of the General Assembly in 1949 and has represented the Philippines at many sessions, said in an interview that flaws in the Charter, such as the veto power in the Security Council, should be corrected to make the document ''more consonant with the times.'' He criticized the United States and the Soviet Union for blocking use of a clause in the Charter that calls for periodic review of its provisions by a conference of member nations.

Spain deployed about 800 paramilitary Civil Guards at the French border today to escort French truck convoys into Spain and prevent further attacks by Basque fishermen who have burned at least 16 vehicles since Sunday.

Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Canada's Foreign Secretary, Allan J. MacEachen, signed a long-sought treaty today to prevent flooding of a scenic river valley and insure a needed energy source for Seattle, Wash. The Skagit River Treaty settlement resolves concerns raised as early as 1942 over the proposed raising of the Ross Dam in the state of Washington, which would have led to the flooding of the Skagit Valley in British Columbia.

Despite ''peace-loving rhetoric'' from Washington, Konstantin U. Chernenko said he had not seen concrete signs of readiness to improve relations with Moscow. ''Alas, the situation in the world is not improving. It remains very dangerous,'' the Soviet leader said, prefacing a gloomy survey of Soviet-American relations to published in the Monday issue of the newspaper Pravda. (Page A1, Col. 1.) World Court jurisdiction in disputes involving Central America will not be accepted by the Reagan Administration for the next two years, the Administration announced. A senior State Department official said the move, which was unexpected, had been taken because of information that Nicaragua was about to bring charges against the United States in the International Court of Justice in The Hague, the official name of the Worl Court. (A1:2.)

The International Court of Justice, often referred to as the World Court, is the main judicial organ of the United Nations. It has no machinery to enforce its decisions, depending instead on moral suasion and world opinion.

The Reagan Administration announced today that it would not accept World Court jurisdiction in disputes involving Central America for the next two years. A senior State Department official said the move, which was unexpected, had been made because of information that Nicaragua was about to bring charges against the United States in the International Court of Justice in The Hague, the official name for the World Court. He said that confidential intelligence reports received last week, as well as some other public signs, led the Administration to conclude that Nicaragua was planning to go to the World Court in coming days. Mining Could Be Issue The United States has been financing activities and reportedly directing anti-Government rebels in Nicaragua, including the mining of waters in and around Nicaraguan harbors. Last week, the United States vetoed a Security Council resolution calling for a halt to such activities. Presumably, if Nicaragua sought relief in the World Court, it would be in connection with this activity, the official said.

Nicaragua asked the World Court today to declare illegal United States support for guerrilla raids on its territory and what it said was Washington's role in the mining of Nicaraguan harbors. In a statement made public by its embassy here today, Nicaragua said that its suit ''asserts that the U.S. Government is training, supplying and directing military and paramilitary actions against the people and Government of Nicaragua, resulting in extensive loss of lives and property,'' in an effort ''to overthrow or destabilize the Government of Nicaragua.'' The Reagan Administration says Nicaragua is trying to overthrow the Salvadoran Government and that the mining of Nicaraguan harbors is therefore justified as a form of self-defense for El Salvador and its allies. It has said that it is supporting anti-Government insurgents in Nicaragua to stop arms it says Nicaragua is sending to Salvadoran guerrillas.

The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., said today that the Reagan Administration's request for $21 million in new aid to Nicaraguan rebels would not be approved by the House. ''I can't conceive of it passing the House,'' Mr. O'Neill, a Massachusetts Democrat, said at a news conference. Mr. O'Neill and Representative Jim Wright, the majority leader, said that reports of the involvement of the Central Intelligence Agency in mining Nicaraguan harbors had killed any chance that the financing measure would be approved. The Republican- controlled Senate approved the bill last week.

What in Hugo Grotius's name is the Reagan Administration doing to America's reputation as a law-abiding society? Grotius was the Dutch jurist who in 1628 first codified the laws of war and peace. As befits a nation founded and governed by lawyers, the United States has repeatedly applied those laws to international behavior; indeed, it declared war on Germany in 1917 when Kaiser Wilhelm's U-boats torpedoed neutral shipping in violation of sea law. In Nicaragua's ports, neutral shipping is now threatened by mines planted with America's connivance, perhaps even by United States agents leading the C.I.A.'s ''contra'' rebels. When challenged by a protest about damage to a Soviet freighter, the Administration condoned the practice, contending that neutrals should have known the waters were dangerous. That is actually the same argument invoked by the German Kaiser.

The Senate, in an angry rebuke to President Reagan, voted overwhelmingly tonight for a resolution that opposed the use of Federal funds to mine Nicaraguan waters. The resolution, which is not binding on the President, was adopted by 84 votes to 12, with the Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., and 41 other Republicans voting against the Administration. Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, was joined by 11 Republicans in opposing the resolution, which was sponsored by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts. The Senate action followed reports from Administration officials and members of Congress that Americans working for the Central Intelligence Agency aboard a ship off Nicaragua were supervising the mining of Nicaragan waters in recent months. 'Reagan's Secret War' The resolution, expressing the ''sense of the Senate,'' reads in full: ''It is the sense of Congress that no funds heretofore or hereafter appropriated in any act of Congress shall be obligated or expended for the purpose of planning, executing or supporting the mining of the ports or territorial waters of Nicaragua.'' ''The Senate took a first step to halt President Reagan's secret war in Nicaragua,'' Senator Kennedy said after the vote. ''Tonight, in a truly bipartisan vote, 84 members of the Senate said 'enough is enough.' ''

The Soviet delegate to the United Nations said today that Nicaragua's harbors were being mined by ''terrorists, supported, equipped and financed by the United States'' in what he called a ''new chapter of international terrorism.'' The delegate, Oleg A. Troyanovsky, also said at a news conference that the Soviet Union and the United States were in ''one of the darkest periods'' in their relations and that an early summit meeting would be counterproductive.

Practically from the outset of the Reagan Administration's ''covert war'' against the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua, there has been confusion and controversy over American objectives. Periodically, President Reagan, reflecting divisions in his Administration, has fueled the argument with imprecision about his goals. The debate also flares with each increase of military pressure by American- backed Nicaraguan rebels. The latest furor has been set off by reports from Reagan Administration officials and members of Congress that Americans not only paid for but also supervised the rebel mining of Nicaraguan ports, prompting Nicaragua to go to the International Court of Justice seeking a legal order to halt the ''covert war.''

Kenneth W. Dam, Deputy Secretary of State, suggested today that the United States would be justified in assisting the mining of Nicaraguan harbors as an act of collective self-defense. Testifying before the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Mr. Dam repeatedly declined to acknowledge that the United States was involved in the mining, as has been reported by Congressional and Administration officials. But he said that if that were the case, it could be justified under collective self- defense clauses of the Charters of both the United Nations and the Organization of American States. ''Collective self-defense is a ground for use of force,'' Mr. Dam said at the outset of a daylong committee session on the Administration's use of money for covert activities in Nicaragua.

Walter F. Mondale today accused President Reagan of pursuing ''misguided'' and ''blundering'' policies in Central America that could lead the United States into war. It was Mr. Mondale's strongest attack yet on the Administration's policies in El Salvador, Nicaragua and Honduras. The candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination said that Mr. Reagan's ''policies are widening, militarizing and Americanizing the conflict every day.'' Mr. Mondale said that, in light of disclosures about the mining of Nicaragauan harbors directed by the Central Intelligence Agency, Mr. Reagan's policies were ''misguided and counterproductive.''

Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that the Government could not practice ''unilateral compliance'' with rules of international law that its adversaries violated with impunity. She also told a group of more than 300 specialists in international law that ''to portray Nicaragua as a victim in the current situation is a complete, Orwellian inversion of what is actually happening in Central America.'' In a speech to a joint luncheon of the American Society of International Law and the Section of International Law and Practice of the American Bar Association, Mrs. Kirkpatrick said the United States and friendly Central American nations had a right to act in ''individual and collective self-defense'' against Nicaraguan aggression. Later today, the American Society of International Law overwhelmingly adopted a resolution that it ''deplores and strongly favors rescission of'' the Reagan Administration's effort to turn aside World Court consideration of Nicaragua's charges that the United States has directed military attacks against it in violation of international law.

To hear Vaughan Aldrich tell it, he and the 7,000 other Mohawk Indians who live here form a sovereign nation whose territory just happens to straddle the border between the United States and Canada. ''My mother always told me never to pay attention to the border between these, what shall we say, these more powerful entities,'' said the Cornell- trained lawyer. He lives and works in Hogansburg, a hamlet on the United States side of the reservation served by the American ZIP code 13655. Just a few hundred yards from his house down an unobstructed two-lane road lies this village with its Canadian post office and its own code, H0M 1A0.

Mexico's Foreign Minister today denounced the mining of Nicaragua's ports as a violation of international law and called for ''the total elimination of all armed violence, direct or indirect, against Nicaragua.'' The Foreign Minister, Bernardo Sepulveda Amor, also asserted that countries cannot on their own withdraw from the jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice. The Reagan Administration announced Sunday that it would not accept decisions by the World Court in disputes over Central America for the next two years. Nicaragua later asked the court to declare United States-backed activities against its territory illegal.

To the Editor: The United States decision to limit acceptance of the jurisdiction of the International Court in order to bar Nicaragua's suit against the U.S. is difficult to sustain in law, since it may require six months' notice. It is much more suspect politically, since it is tantamount to an admission that the other side's case is unimpeachable.

To the Editor: I applaud your opposition to President Reagan's attempt to defeat the jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice in the Nicaragua case (''Illegal, Deceptive and Dumb,'' editorial April 11). However, something more tangible must be done. Senator Kennedy and some of his colleagues should bring suit against the President for what is an unconstitutional infringement upon the recognized right of the Senate to give its advice and consent to all treaties concluded on behalf of the United States.

International law dictates broad immunity for accredited diplomats and makes embassy grounds inviolable, limiting the British Government's ability to act against those responsible for the shootings from the Libyan Embassy in London today. Experts said that even a murder suspect who enjoys diplomatic status would be immune from criminal prosecution, and that the British police would ordinarily be barred from entering the Libyan Embassy without the consent of its officers. On the other hand, the British Government could expel any or all Libyan diplomats from its territory, close the embassy and prosecute any suspect who does not have diplomatic immunity, experts said. In addition, the fact that the Libyan Embassy in London was taken over and its accredited diplomats were ejected by revolutionary students in February, without formal notification to the British authorities, could cast doubt on whether those now occupying the embassy were entitled to diplomatic immunity.

The World Court met today to discuss Nicaragua's accusation that the United States is sponsoring attacks against the Central American country. The United States asserts that the court has no jurisdiction in the issue. The president of the court, Taslim Olawale Elias of Nigeria, asked both nations to act in such a way that any court order would ''have its appropriate effect,'' said a court spokesman. In accordance with court policy, he spoke on condition of anonymity.

The United States has raised a new challenge to the World Court's jurisdiction in the Nicaraguan lawsuit, arguing that Nicaragua has no standing to sue because it never consented to be sued. The court rejected the argument today and said a public hearing in the case would be held Wednesday as scheduled. The 15-member tribunal, formally known as the International Court of Justice, will convene at 10 A.M. to hear Nicaragua's request for an intermediate halt to the United States' sponsorship of armed attacks. The latest American challenge and the court's decision were disclosed by Paul S. Reichler, a Washington lawyer representing Nicaragua, in a telephone interview today from The Hague, the seat of the World Court.

To the Editor: Prof. Francis A. Boyle (letter April 17) recommends that Senator Kennedy and other Senators bring suit against President Reagan for his unilateral action in defeating the jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice in the Nicaragua case. Failure to bring such a suit, says the professor, ''would establish a very unhealthy precedent for future Presidents to engage, acting on their own accord, in similar unilateral amendments of U.S. treaty commitments.'' On the contrary, in view of the Supreme Court case of Goldwater v. Carter (444 U.S. 996 (1979)) it is the bringing of such a suit which would create precedent for unilateral Presidential action regarding treaties.

Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch yesterday incorrectly described an action by the International Court of Justice on Nicaragua's lawsuit requesting an immediate halt to the United States' sponsorship of military attacks against its territory.

Nicaragua called on the World Court today to issue a restraining order to stop the United States from supporting military activities against the Sandinista Government. Nicaragua's attorneys, making their appeal before the 15-member Court in the Great Hall of Justice of the Peace Palace here, asked the Court for ''interim measures of protection.'' Essentially this protection would be a ban on all United States military activities relating to Nicaragua while the Court examines the Nicaraguan application to declare that United States support for guerrilla groups fighting the Managua Government is illegal. Lawyers for the United States were not heard during the first day of proceedings. After the first presentations today, Davis R. Robinson, legal adviser to the State Department, described the Nicaraguan arguments before the Court as ''basically political.''

The United States urged the International Court of Justice today to reject Nicaragua's attempt to obtain a restraining order banning all American military activities against the Sandinista Government. State Department lawyers, replying to Nicaragua's request here on Wednesday for ''interim measures of protection,'' asserted that the World Court lacked jurisdiction because, they said, Nicaragua had never filed an official statement of ratification accepting the Court's compulsory jurisdiction. Without being able to show that it has ratified its adherence to the Court's decisions - literally, furnishing the ratification document to the Court - Nicaragua, the United States argued, could not sue or be sued in it. Says U.S. Is Trying 'to Flee' In reply, Carlos Arg"uello Gomez, the chief Nicaraguan representative and a former Justice Minister, accused the United States of trying ''to flee the justice of international law'' by focusing on the issue of jurisdiction.

To the Editor: Michael Ledeen writes: ''If the crit ics of our Central American policy were morally consistent, they would demand that Cuba and Nicaragua be brought before international tribunals for their aggression against El Salvador, for the Cuban sponsorship of drugs and terror and for the Nicaraguan repression of its own people.'' I am one of those critics, and I should like to see these charges brought before the International Court of Justice. The Administration could easily do so either by joining El Salvador in bringing a case or by responding to the Nicaraguan charge before the I.C.J. That would be morally and legally consistent. SEYMOUR M. FINGER Professor of Political Science Graduate School, CUNY New York, April 18, 1984

Walter F. Mondale charged today that President Reagan had failed to demonstrate proper respect for the law. The former Vice President signaled that he planned to make questions of law and ethics a major component of his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination. ''Sometimes I think this Administration thinks that executing laws means shooting them,'' Mr. Mondale said in a speech at the University of Notre Dame, ''From the day the President entered office, he and his people have been reading selectively from the United States Code and picking and choosing the laws they wished to enforce.'' Mr. Mondale's appearance here was the centerpiece of a day of campaigning in Indiana and Ohio, which together account for 231 of the 368 delegates that Democrats are to select in primaries on May 8. His aides described today's speech as a preview of one of the themes the Mondale campaign expects to use against President Reagan if the Minnesotan prevails in his nomination struggle against Senator Gary Hart of Colorado and the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

To the people of this hilly fishing village, the hub of Canada's scallop fishing industry, their economic fate hangs on a case that the United States has been pressing before the International Court of Justice at The Hague. The United States says it owns the Georges Bank, an area between Nova Scotia and New England where scallop fishing is done. Canada says it owns slightly less than half of it. Canada contends that, if the United States wins, the effect might be to force 3,600 fishermen and workers in support industries in Lunenburg and other areas along the Nova Scotia coast off the job.

The Interior Department proposed today to open 14 million acres in the North Atlantic to offshore oil and gas leasing, but more than half the area is claimed by Canada. The plan involves an offshore area stretching from Maine to New Jersey. The department said the area disputed by Canada would be leased only if the United States received a favorable ruling from the World Court. Canada has claimed about half the Georges Bank fishing region off New England.

Following is the text of the preliminary restraining order issued today by the International Court of Justice against the United States on a complaint filed by Nicaragua: THE HAGUE, May 10 (AP) - Following is the text of the preliminary restraining order issued today by the International Court of Justice against the United States on a complaint filed by Nicaragua: THE COURT, A. Unanimously, REJECTS the request made by the United States of America that the proceedings on the application filed by the Republic of Nicaragua on 9 April 1984, and on the request filed the same day by the Republic of Nicaragua for the indication of provisional measures, be terminated by the removal of the case from the list. B. Indicates, PENDING its final decision in the proceedings instituted on 9 April 1984 by the Republic of Nicaragua against the United States of America, the following provisional measures: 1. UNANIMOUSLY,THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICAshould immediately cease and refrain from any action restricting, blocking or endangering access to or from Nicaraguan ports, and, in particular, the laying of mines.

It also deplored President Reagan's appeal for more aid for the Salvadoran Government. Government radio broadcasts hailed the ruling by the 15-judge International Court of Justice as a victory for Nicaragua and ''the first condemnation of American imperialistic policies in Central America.''

Text of ruling is on page A9. THE HAGUE, May 10 - The International Court of Justice ruled unanimously today that the United States should immediately halt any attempts to blockade or mine Nicaraguan ports. The World Court, granting Nicaragua's request for a preliminary restraining order to protect its sovereign rights, also asserted by a vote of 14 to 1 that Nicaragua's political independence ''should be fully respected and should not be jeopardized by any military or paramilitary activities.'' (Reacting to the interim ruling, the Unites States said it found nothing it could not accept in the decision, including the call for an end to the mining of Nicaraguan harbors. American officials have said the mining ended in late March and will not be resumed. Page A8.)

The interim decision handed down in The Hague yesterday in Nicaragua's case against the United States was rendered by a 15-member court headed by a Nigerian and including judges from the United States, Britain, France, West Germany and the Soviet Union. The judicial body, the International Court of Justice, whose decisions are nonbinding recommendations, was created in 1945 under a statute that is part of the United Nations Charter. The statute says those on the Court should be ''independent judges elected regardless of their nationality from among persons of high moral character, who possess the qualifications required in their respective countries for appointment to the highest judicial offices.'' 9-Year Terms for Judges Only one national from a country is allowed. The judges are elected by the General Assembly and the Security Council for nine-year terms and may be re-elected.

Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 28. 1. This was a noteworthy discovery. Explain. 2. In terrorist attacks, an armed man stormed a Government building in one country and 20 gunmen reportedly stormed a barracks usually used as a residence in another country. What countries are they and who was the target in each case?

WASHINGTON P OLITICAL moods in Washington often last, as a Scandinavian Ambassador put it, ''about as long as the flight of a chicken.'' Just three weeks ago the tide was running against President Reagan's Central American policy because Capitol Hill was in an uproar over the mining of Nicaraguan harbors. Last week, the tide turned. The harbor mining was barely mentioned in Congress and the President won a tight but important legislative vote authorizing more military aid to El Salvador. The shift reflected not only Washington's quixotic moods on Central America, but also the perpetual tug-of-war in the post-Vietnam era over any foreign policy that involves a conspicuous use of force. Congress had cooled off during its Easter recess as the headlines concentrated on President Reagan's trip to China. And the President, in a nationally televised appeal Wednesday night, made the dire prediction that ''the Communists will succeed'' in El Salvador unless Congress voted more aid. To Democrats, that sounded like an election-year warning that he would hold them harshly to account if the Salvadoran Government fell. In fact, officials said the President had toned down earlier speech drafts, which accused his critics of being as blind toward the Communist threat as some Europeans had been to Hitler in the 1930's. He dropped a defiant reference to the harbor mining after Senate Republican leaders said it would rekindle partisan passions.

A five-judge panel of the International Court of Justice heard final arguments today in the dispute between the United States and Canada about their maritime boundary in the Gulf of Maine, the area of the Atlantic Ocean that includes the rich Georges Bank fishing zone. The panel will now deliberate on thousands of pages of testimony going back to November 1981, when the two countries agreed to submit the case to the World Court. A decision is expected in August. By mutual agreement, it will be binding.

The International Commission of Jurists today condemned the decision by the United States not to recognize the jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice on matters relating to Latin America. The United States move was announced April 6, before a ruling by the World Court last Friday that the United States should stop attempts to blockade or mine Nicaraguan ports.

Singing a song about the sadness of exile, a delegation of Pacific islanders pleaded here today for help in enabling the people of Bikini atoll to return to their homeland, the site between 1946 and 1958 of 23 nuclear test explosions. ''We want to return to our homeland, not a dangerously contaminated Bikini, but a clean one, a Bikini that is safe for us and our children's children,'' Tomaki Juda, the mayor of the atoll, told the United Nations Trusteeship Council today. ''We want to sail our lagoon, fish our reef, and be a free people again.'' Mr. Juda's appearance in the airy, nearly empty Trusteeship Council chamber this morning was part of an effort made by various Pacific islanders to gain support for claims of compensation they are making against the United States Government because of nuclear testing in the Marshall Islands years ago.
To the Editor: A myth seems to be developing according to which the International Court of Justice (I.C.J.) can make only ''nonbinding recommendations'' (news story May 11). This just is not so.

Canada has protested United States moves to sell offshore oil leases in territory whose ownership the two nations dispute. In a note delivered to the State Department on Monday, Canada protested a notice in the Federal Register on March 30 that asked oil companies to indicate areas they might be interested in leasing off southern Alaska. Canada contends that some of the 25 million acres involved belong to British Columbia.

The Director General of Unesco warned the United States today that it might still have to pay about $43 million in its 1985 budget contribution to the organization even if it withdraws at the end of this year. The Director General, Amadou Mahtar M'Bow, said that if the United States refused to pay the money, other countries on Unesco's 51-member executive board might take the Reagan Administration before the International Court of Justice in the Hague. The United States Delegate, Jean Broward Shevlin Gerard, firmly rejected Mr. M'Bow's assertion, which was made during a meeting of Unesco's executive board to discuss demands by the United States and other Western countries for far-reaching changes in the way the organization operates. The United States has said it will withdraw from Unesco if the changes are not made.

After more than three years of political controversy over United States policy in Central America, President Reagan and Democratic leaders in Congress are in a power struggle over the Administration's once-covert war against Nicaragua. The President and Republican leaders in the Senate and House of Representatives are battling to continue aid to Nicaraguan rebels through the Central Intelligence Agency. But the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., and many House Democratic liberals are intent upon ending it. Passions have risen to the point where both sides proclaim the operation is not only an acutely important foreign policy issue but also a test of American character. Proponents of the program contend that it would be immoral now to abandon the rebels, and opponents say the covert war was immoral from the outset.

Of all the Indian subcontinent's myriad religious groups, few are considered more influential in the secular world for their size than an energetic, tightly organized group that calls itself the Ahmadiya. The Ahmadis are adherents of a 100- year-old faith rooted in Islam but modified by Christianity. From their headquarters in this green oasis town of 40,000 people set among stark, craggy peaks jutting up from the surrounding plains of the Pakistani Punjab, the Ahmadis propagate a world view enlivened by a strong tradition of scholarship and learning. Pakistan's only Nobel Prize winner, the physicist Abdus Salam, is an Ahmadi. So was this country's first Foreign Minister, Sir Chaudhry Zafrullah Khan, who also became a president of the United Nations General Assembly and a judge of the International Court of Justice. So were, and are, several people who occupy key posts in Pakistan's Government and Army.

Four years after the United States Supreme Court upheld nearly $106 million in compensation to the Indians for the Black Hills of South Dakota, the Sioux here have still not received the money, and many say they do not want it. Despite the poverty of the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, tribal leaders say they would rather have the land they hold sacred than have the award. They have begun a campaign to regain the Black Hills through the courts, Congress or international pressure. ''The U.S. Government has a battle on its hands,'' said Lyman Red Cloud, a tribal council member who is a descendant of the 19th-century war chief, Red Cloud. ''They can't force this money down the Indians' throats.''

President Jose Napoleon Duarte says he will file a complaint with the International Court of Justice accusing Nicaragua's Government of smuggling weapons to leftist rebels in El Salvador. ''In some manner, we have to stop this influx of weapons,'' Mr. Duarte said at a news conference on Friday.

When the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace, the West Coast research organization, first sought out John C. Shepherd in 1977, it was looking for a good lawyer to represent its interests in a complicated case involving a bequest in Missouri. While working on the case, Mr. Shepherd, whose practice is based in St. Louis, met most of the officers of the institution. Shortly thereafter the institution, which is affiliated with Stanford University, named him to its Board of Overseers and its executive committee. The story of Mr. Shepherd's tie to the Hoover Institution, an organization with close ties to the Reagan Administration, reflects more than his political philosophy.

Forty years ago tomorrow, limousines glided through the gates of the imposing Dumbarton Oaks estate on the edge of the Georgetown section of Washington, bringing leaders of four nations to a meeting that would set much of the framework for drafting of the United Nations Charter. The Dumbarton Oaks Conference, it was eventually called. But to the cautious diplomats from the United States, Britain, the Soviet Union and China who spent weeks working on the proposals, the meeting was more simply referred to as ''Washington Conversations on International Organization,'' so as to indicate that the talks were being held below the foreign minister level and would thus not produce binding commitments. The brick Dumbarton Oaks mansion is still here, still owned by Harvard University and now serving as a museum and research center offering fellowships to scholars in the fields of Byzantine and pre-Columbian art, as well as the history of landscape architecture. It is the site of various traveling exhibits, such as a current one on the master plan of a monastic settlement in Switzerland. Meanwhile, the magnificent terraced gardens on the estate have become a favorite tourist oasis in the midst of a busy city.

Producing and sowing these weapons takes logistic skills that only governments normally possess. More than most forms of terrorism, this is an act of war, and one that thrusts indiscriminately at the navigation rights of all nations. What was unfortunately true when the C.I.A. arranged for the ''nuisance'' mining of Nicaragua's harbors is even more plainly true in the Middle East. Egypt's President Mubarak deserves help, and America's wiser second thoughts in Nicaragua made it much easier to help him get it.

The Reagan Administration said today that it had decided to back ratification of a 36- year-old United Nations convention against genocide. With the Senate in session for only three more weeks, officials acknowledged that the chances for early approval were slim, making the announcement largely symbolic. The officials said that, if President Reagan were re-elected in November, he would press for approval in the next Congress. The convention was adopted in 1948 in response to the killing of six million Jews by the German Nazis. It defines genocide as the commission of certain acts ''with intent to destroy, in whole or in part, a national, ethnic, racial or religious group'' and obliges countries that are parties to it to prevent and punish genocide.

Senator Jesse Helms, in a clash with Senator Charles H. Percy, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, blocked a committee vote today for at least 24 hours and possibly a week on a United Nations convention against genocide. Senator Percy, a moderate Republican from Illinois who like Senator Helms, Republican of North Carolina, is engaged in a heated re-election campaign, sought to obtain a committee vote today on the 36-year-old convention. The Reagan Administration announced Sept. 5 that it would seek approval of the treaty.

Outlook Less Gloomy for Aliens Bill With time running out on Capitol Hill, the prospects for an overhaul of the immigration laws seemed to improve a bit last week. Conferees, belatedly turning to the many differences between bills approved by the House and Senate, agreed to make it illegal for an employer to hire any alien known to have entered the United States illegally. Any number of controversial issues are still to be dealt with, including a proposal for a temporary foreign worker program that would allow aliens into the country to help harvest crops.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today recommended approval of a United Nations convention outlawing genocide, but it is uncertain whether the measure will reach the Senate floor before Congress adjourns. The committee's 17-to-0 vote came as Presidential and Congressional candidates sought to court Jewish voters. President Reagan announced his endorsement of the treaty Sept. 5, a day before he addressed a national convention of B'nai B'rith, a Jewish service organization. Senator Jesse Helms, a North Carolina Republican who had delayed committee action for a week, voted ''present.'' But the senator later joined in a unanimous vote that urged the Senate leadership ''to proceed immediately to consideration of the genocide convention, and seek to complete action on it prior to adjournment.''

The World Court announced at The Hague today that it had rejected El Salvador's petition to intervene on the side of the United States in arguing that the Court should not decide Nicaragua's lawsuit against the United States. The 15-judge body made the ruling public without explanation.

The World Court settled a two-decade-old territorial dispute between the United States and Canada today, awarding the United States about two- thirds of the Gulf of Maine and giving Canada the rest. The case involves 30,000 square nautical miles of the sea, most important the Georges Bank, a series of shoals and reefs whose abundance of cod, flounder, haddock and scallops has made it one of the world's richest fishing grounds. The United States had said it was entitled to a boundary line that would put all of the Georges Bank under American jurisdiction; Canada wanted a line that would give it half the area. As a result of the court's decision, Canadian and American fishermen will have 14 days to move to their own side of the new line.

A World Court decision that gave Canada a section of the Georges Bank fishing ground could hurt New England's fishing industry, cut this country's seafood harvest and drive up consumer prices, industry and government officials say. ''On balance, the United States came out much worse,'' said James Warren, a member of the New England Fisheries Management Council who is head of the Maine Sardine Council. ''The fishermen have lost areas they have been fishing in for 300 years.''

A fatalistic attitude comes easily to residents of this hilly fishing town. Over the centuries, dozens of its ships and hundreds of its sons have been lost at sea. The town, which is the hub of Canada's scallop fishing industry, was shaken last week by a different event beyond its control. The International Court of Justice at The Hague resolved a maritime boundary dispute between Canada and the United States by giving the northern nation just a third of the disputed 30,000 square nautical miles in the Gulf of Maine.

Following are key sections of Judge Ilario Martella's report, filed today, on the shooting of Pope John Paul II in 1981, as translated by The New York Times from the Italian: The attempt on the life of the Sovereign Pontiff, John Paul II, which took place in St. Peter's Square on May 13, 1981, represents a monstrous crime against all humanity, as it has offended the conscience of all those who, whether belonging to a religious group or not, recognize the basic Christian values of peace, brotherhood and solidarity for which the Pope seems the most logical standard bearer. Those principles which in fact are contained in every philosophical and historical ideology that does not propose as its end the destruction of man. We have here, therefore, a real act of war against the most authentic lasting values of the civilized world (today more than ever struggling for its own survival and conservation), offended and humiliated by a ''provocation'' that has no precedent in history.

A Chinese judge was named to the World Court today, becoming the first representative of the Peking Government on the court since the nation was admitted to the United Nations. Ni Zhengyu, 78 years old, a legal counsel in the Chinese Foreign Ministry, was elected by the United Nations General Assembly and Security Council to the court, formally known as the International Court of Justice, which sits in The Hague.

The Monroe Doctrine, largely shunned by United States officials for the past 30 years, has had a minor revival amid the recent round of official hints that military force might be used to curb Soviet arming of Nicaragua. References by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and others to the 161-year-old doctrine coincide with apparent adoption by the Administration of a view of international law that gives the United States considerable leeway to use force against Nicaragua. State Department lawyers have broadly construed the right of self-defense against ''armed attack'' recognized in the United Nations Charter. They told the International Court of Justice last month that United States actions against Nicaragua were ''collective self-defense'' against Nicaraguan support of leftist guerrillas in El Salvador and elsewhere.

At midnight Tuesday, an hour north of here, Leonardo Taormina's boat slipped back through the glittering black water beneath the old houses and steeples that encircle the harbor of Gloucester and came into port. His boat, The Taormina, a stern trawler 87 feet long, had been out for 10 days, 240 hours of constant fishing, dragging the ocean floor for haddock, cod, flounder. ''Whatever is on the bottom, we drag it off,'' he said. He spent three days sweeping the underwater contours of Cashes Ledge, 85 miles east of Cape Ann, catching ''a few flounder, some pollock,'' and then he dragged his nets another 80 or 90 miles to the edge of the new American/ Canadian fishing boundary established in the Gulf of Maine by the International Court of Justice, wishing he could cross over. His last trip out, he had brought back 90,000 pounds of fish, and it would have been 150,000, he thought, if he could have dragged the deep, fertile waters on the Canadian side of Georges Bank.

Reagan Administration officials said today that the World Court's ruling that it had jurisdiction to decide Nicaragua's lawsuit against the United States would force Washington to consider whether to boycott further proceedings. Officials following the case said the 15-to-1 decision seemed to portend that the Court might eventually uphold Nicaragua's contention that the United States violated international law by supporting military attacks against Nicaragua and order an end to such support. The chief White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, said, ''We are disappointed with the Court's decision.'' He added, referring to four Latin American nations' efforts to solve the region's disputes, that the ruling ''will be harmful to the Contadora negotiations and will, accordingly, hinder rather than help achieve peace in Central America.''

The World Court ruled today that it had jurisdiction to hear a case brought by Nicaragua that is aimed at declaring the United States an aggressor country. The Court voted, 15 to 1, against United States arguments that it had no jurisdiction in the matter. It then unanimously rejected the United States argument that it should not decide the case even if it had jurisdiction. The Court also ruled that preliminary restraining orders it issued against the United States in May, at Nicaragua's request, should remain in force pending resolution of the case. These called on the United States to halt any attempts to blockade or mine Nicaraguan ports and to refrain from jeopardizing Nicaragua's political independence by any military or paramilitary activities.

Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 28. 1. This embrace concluded a historic event. Who are the people embracing and what was the event? 2. Naltrexone, a substance that is said to block an addict's craving for heroin without creating a new addiction, has been approved by the Food and Drug Administration. However, officials in the drug treatment field say it cannot be administered to the majority of addicts. What is the reason?

Already a standard target of attacks in the United Nations General Assembly, the United States last week seemed to be on a collision course with another world forum, the International Court of Justice. Some legal experts see the conflict - over the Court's ruling that it has the power to judge Reagan Administration actions against Nicaragua - as the latest step in a gradual withering of the United States' commitment to the system of international institutions it helped set up after World War II. Administration officials, however, contend that they have operated effectively in these organizations. The World Court's 15-to-1 decision to consider the Nicaraguan claim that United States support for military attacks against the Sandinistas has violated international law set the stage for a vote on whether to condemn the United States as an aggressor. Lawyers for the United States are pessimistic about the outcome.

To the Editor: The landmark decision of the International Court of Justice, holding that the United States must answer charges of aggression in Nicaragua (news article, Nov. 27), offers our Government an unparalleled opportunity to advance the cause of world peace. Acceptance of the decision would be consistent with our finest traditions and aspirations.

In the Gloucester harbor north of here, where fishermen have brought their catch to dock for more than 350 years, the curved hulls and rigging of the fishing trawlers make a pretty sight. But some of the oldest boats, and some of the newest, are not at dock, nor will they be again. Thirty-seven trawlers, almost a quarter of the Gloucester fleet, have sunk in the last four years, and most lie in deep waters off the coast, in silent monument to a troubled trade. Across the continent, dozens of boats used to fish for Alaskan king crabs have gone down in the Bering Sea. From Alaska to California, from Maine south and around into the Gulf of Mexico, the commercial fishing fleet is embattled by changing times. Faced here and there with diminished fish stocks and increased foreign competition, the industry has been rocked in recent years by an increased number of sinkings in both high seas and calm, prompting suspicion among fishermen and insurers that some boats have been sent under intentionally.

To the Editor: The options for the United States in connection with the recent decision of the World Court on the application of Nicaragua are more, or more refined, than the three listed in ''The United States Has a Bad Day in World Court'' (Week in Review, Dec. 2). The article suggests that the U.S. had to decide to boycott the proceedings; delay in the hope that the issue would be settled by negotiation, or just comply with the Court's order. The first two have obvious disadvantages. The third, however, could be modified usefully. The U.S. could well show up for the further argument of the case, while at the same time arguing - with considerable merit - that some of the issues were already moot and others were not justiciable.

To the Editor: For as long as we have existed as a nation, the United States has been an outspoken advocate of the rule of law in relations between nation states. It is with considerable embarrassment and chagrin that I read the procedural argument put forth by the Department of State to attack the jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice to hear Nicaragua's case against alleged U.S. aggression.

The Interior Department today canceled the second part of a scheduled sale of oil leases off New England, citing lack of industry interest and a court decision that placed much of the area under Canadian jurisdiction. The first part of the sale, which included the Georges Bank fishing ground, was canceled in September after no bids were received for the available tracts except for those submitted by Greenpeace, a conservation group that opposed the sale. The department also announced that it would defer setting a date for still another sale of offshore oil leases in the area until a new five-year plan for the development of the outer continental shelf was completed.

PEKING In many respects, Haidianlu is much like any other street in Peking. It is windblown, dusty and crowded with bicycles. But here, not far from Peking University and the Chinese Academy of Sciences, is to be found one of the cutting edges of the new revolution with which Chinese leaders hope to sweep the country into prosperity in the 21st century. China is in the full bloom of a love affair with the computer, and the signs of it are everywhere. In the past two years, computer shops have been springing up along streets like Haidianlu in most major cities here, offering the latest in microcomputers, software and ancillary equipment. Most of the wares are Japanese and American; the rest are close copies originating with China's own fledgling industry.

President Reagan has decided that the Government will not take part in further World Court proceedings in Nicaragua's suit against the United States, the State Department announced today. The action marked the first time the United States has walked out of a case in the World Court, in defiance of the Court's rules, since joining the tribunal in 1946. The Court is formally known as the International Court of Justice. In a separate development, senior Administration officials said the United States had suspended the negotiations it began with Nicaragua last June over Central American security and related problems. The officials said the Nicaraguans seemed uninterested in serious exchanges. The Nicaraguan Deputy Foreign Minister deplored the suspension. (Page 4.)

Following is the text of a statement made public today by the State Department and called ''U.S. Withdrawal From the Proceedings Initiated by Nicaragua in the International Court of Justice'': The United States has consistently taken the position that the proceedings initiated by Nicaragua in the International Court of Justice are a misuse of the Court for political purposes and that the Court lacks jurisdiction and competence over such a case. The Court's decision of Nov. 26, 1984, finding that it has jurisdiction, is contrary to law and fact.
